novel_text:
The gutters sang in a broken way whenever it rained, and it rained most days of the week. Pipes were throats here; ducts had moods. The men on the street yelled and jostled and honked, flung coffee cups into storm drains as if they were shooting free throws, slapped fenders when they had to wait longer than a breath. The city had built itself into a nervous system of elbows and horn-blasts. Everyone said it had always been this way. No one rememberd it any other way.

Orla Vale kept her wrench against her shoulder in the manner of a rifle, not because she liked the look but because men left her alone if she resembled a silhouette they respected. It was not much of a trick. Sometimes it worked. Sometimes the silhouette just attracted more noise. Her van was white with a fading logo—Vale & Daughter, even though the first Vale had been her mother and there had never been a son and there would be, likely, no daughter. A hand-painted mermaid had been on the side panel once, then someone graffitied sunglasses onto it, then someone else knifed the mermaid’s tail into a forked devil-leg. Orla never bothered to repaint it. There were always more leaks.

She liked the sound of a blown trap, the slurp and low shiver. The old apartments were made of pipes and wishful thinking. If you listened long enough, you could hear chords in the water. She had heard music there since she was a kid, crouched under the sink while her mother taught her to fit a coupling, tinny radio tuned to something pop and bright. Her grandfather, Rowan Vale, sat in the doorway with his hands knotted like hose bibbs and told stories about rivers that ran sweet as tea and didn’t smell like coins. He always told stories while somebody’s hands were in the dark.

Now the mermaids were all defaced and the rivers were recipes for rust, and men who did not even know their fathers had the voice of the city. They shouted. They cut in line. They were reckless with their cars, with their mouths, with their newborns. They joked about getting “the pickles” whenever a job smelled of brine. They didn’t hold doors. They said Smile at her when she carried a pipe cutter the weight of a toddler, or else they said Hey plumber girl, you should stick to drains, and then, after she’d fixed a thing too crooked and sour for their own hands to address, they said I could’ve done that and made it look easy. Orla carried her wrench like a rifle and smiled with her teeth and billed them double.

The day the sink exploded in the Pickling Works, she had to go in through the wrong door because the foreman sent her to the alley and told her she’d like the view. “Valerie!” he said, loud and wrong. “Around back! Bring your girly hands. The sink’s sulking.”

“My name is Orla,” she said, but you can’t correct a man like that because he isn’t listening; he’s preloading the next joke. She went to the alley anyway. It smelled like vinegar and copper and two storms ago. She should have been angry but she wasn’t. It was a feeling like a frayed wire: if she touched it, she’d give out some of her electricity and have nothing left for later. So she didn’t touch it. She went in through the wrong door and into a room where cucumbers swam in hotel pans and a boy in a hairnet juggled six rubber stoppers for the fun of it. He wasn’t supposed to be juggling. He shouldn’t have been smiling. But there it is: the rude and the reckless often use the same spoons.

The sink was sulking. It was the sort of sulking that spelled catastrophe later in the week, and Orla had not yet been paid for last month’s catastrophe. She kneeled. The underbelly of machinery had the heat and chatter of crowded public buses. A grated floor. Vinegar sloshing. “Who installed this?” she asked.

The foreman curled his lip. “A man,” he said, as if that blessed it.

“This elbow is misthreaded.” She tapped it and heard it cry, a faint ring. She smiled despite herself. The pipes did sing, sometimes. You needed the right patient ear. “Sit there,” she said to the foreman. “If it goes wrong, hold the crate up. Don’t let the faucet bend.” She handed him a crate. He blinked as if she had passed him a swaddled infant.

“I am paid to—” he began.

“You are paid, yes,” she said, and shoved herself farther into the crawl. Up close the pipe told her about stress, and the bend told her about pride, and the leak whispered in a thin note about the way the brine ran warmer this week. The Pickling Works had changed a recipe. Without telling anyone downstream. She looked toward the boy, who’d paused his juggling to watch. “What did you change?”

“Less dill,” he said helplessly. “More alum. Chef says it makes the crunch sharper. A sharper crunch sells.”

“No one ever sells the taste of patience,” Orla said to herself, and then her wrench bit the pipe.

This was all before the song.

When she was fourteen her grandfather Rowan took her to the Library of Wet Things—the part of the municipal archives where maps of sewers and flood plans were stored in rolling cabinets. He had a friend there, a quiet almost-woman named Jun with hair like a question mark. That was Jun before she cut it into a flag. “It’s not the maps,” he said, holding Orla’s hand when they still walked slow together. “It’s the notations. Men drew these lines, sure, but others wrote the notes. If you want to know a city, read the notes that got written anyway.” The librarian looked like she had laughter behind her teeth but never let it out.

Jun Reid looked up from a tray of blueprint onionskins, nodding to Rowan first. Men liked it when you greeted them first, even the soft ones. “Rowan Vale. You’ve a child.”

“I’ve an apprentice plumber,” Rowan said. “And a songwriter, though she won’t admit to it since her mother told her songs don’t pay the rent. Show her the thing?”

“The thing,” Jun said. “Ah. The Thing.” She led them to a cabinet marked Unclassified and inside it another marked Oral Traditions Reference. There was a file with a label faded to a bruise. Consumption of Ancestral Voice, she read aloud. Orla made a face and Rowan squeezed her hand.

“Silly,” he murmured. “Scary on purpose.”

Jun spread the file like a fish on the table. The papers smelled of an attic. “The city had this once,” she said. “An old immigrant thing. Some families—I suppose your mother’s people—believed the first singer ate something of the last singer, so the voice wouldn’t be random. Chefs, too, but they had spicier rules. It was never codified law here, but it got into the machinery accidentally. A registry line. A clerical side-door. Systems don’t notice they are doing it. The world—that loud rude part—keeps forgetting who built the quiet rules under the noise.” She shrugged with one shoulder. “We’ve all eaten worse, metaphorically.”

“I don’t like it,” Orla said, because she was fourteen and because she did like the feeling of a secret being threaded slowly through her like ribbon. It made her feel chosen and angry at the same time. “It’s gross.”

Jun Reid, whose shoulders knew more than one shrug, said, “Gross doesn’t mean untrue. It might just mean someone wanted you to stop asking questions.” She watched Rowan for a long second. “This file shouldn’t exist. I like knowing it does.”

Rowan told her while they walked home across a bridge bolted together like a sentence. “Some things you wear like armor,” he said. “Some—like this—you put in your pocket and don’t take out unless it’s raining and your shoes are already wet and you need to know there’s at least a bus schedule.”

“I’m not eating you,” Orla said, halfway laughing and halfway not.

“Good,” Rowan said. “I’m not a carrot. I prefer to be boiled down into a ghost like everyone else.”

Now Rowan coughed whenever he laughed. Now he coughed when he breathed. He had a cough like sand. “Men are ruder than they’ve ever been,” he said one night while Orla tried to make the beans taste like anything. “Or I’m more patient than I’ve ever been. I can’t tell.” He took a teaspoon of beans as if it would lick him back. “You still hearing the songs?”

“I hear everything,” she said. “And nothing you can sell.” She was lying. She had a verse about the drips in Building Nine that made her blush in the bath when she sang it to herself. She had a chorus about the municipal ditch that came to her in a thunderclap while she ran conduit through a landlord’s very expensive vanity. She wrote the lines on back of receipts and then used the receipts to track down men who owed her late money because life is never for one thing only.

Her phone bleated. A payment app: partial. A message: come fix the valve again, lady, you did it wrong. She looked at the amount and laughed. “If you’re going to insult me,” she texted back, “do it with more money.” She did not press send. The words were, as the saying goes, clumsy armor.

The men at the Pickling Works were yelling because a sink threw its guts back at them. She fixed it. She sent her invoice and when the foreman made the wrong face, she told him his elbows were misthreaded too. She went home with brine in her hair and Rowan asleep in his chair. Jun had left a note in the flower pot—a woman who worked at the orbital yard came by the Library to look at lift designs, lovely odd curve to her; here’s her number; she said she remembered you changing a gasket at the yard faster than any of the men. Jun never wrote straightforward notes. They were always sentences with knots, leaving you to pick loose the threads.

The orbital yard sat at the edge of the salt flats, shining with opinionated cranes. The rockets had been a rumor for as long as Orla remembered, something to point to like a lighthouse: proof that one day someone would leave. Men always said it wouldn’t work, that the yard was a scam, that fuel just hadn’t been invented yet or else it was too expensive for this city. Men said a lot of things. A woman with the odd lovely curve to her handwriting called herself Keziah Idowu and had grease under her nails that didn’t come from cars. “You come by twice a season,” Keziah said. “I remember your hands. You reach into machines like you expect them to be blessed. Most of our men reach like machines are dogs that might bite.”

“They are dogs that might bite,” Orla said. “But if you make your hands into good hands, they don’t.” She blushed. It sounded like she was describing something else.

“The pumps by the fuel tank are whining,” Keziah said, pretending not to notice the blush. Then she noticed. “You should laugh when you want to laugh,” she added softly. “They’ll pretend you’re laughing at them anyway.”

Orla fixed the pump. She put her ear to the flange and heard a B-flat gossiping with a low E. She could almost hear a verse. Something snappy, something bright. She didn’t write it then. She could hear the world behind the rocket yard—men in the parking lot bragging that they’d squeezed an extra mile out of a gallon by gutting the safety valve, a boy selling an e-cigarette under a sign that said NO FIRE. She thought: this city is going to pickle itself like it pickles cucumbers—packed into brine and burning our tongues.

She had applied to the Registry of Song twice and been rejected twice because she had no Agent-of-Record and because her trust score was contaminated by late payments and because one of the gatekeepers had marked her as uncooperative. You could not simply publish your own song anymore, not if you wanted anyone in the city to hear it with the volume turned up. You had to go through a gate, and all the gatekeepers were men, and if they weren’t men they were software written by men and taught by men to recognize what sounding like a man.

Jun told her, in the Library, over a thermos of coffee that had more bitterness than contentment, “They’ve got a backdoor and they forgot they built it. Remember the file I showed you? The one you didn’t like? It sits under the layer-cake of permits like a fossil. If you can speak with an ancestor’s signature, the registry auto-accepts and routes around the gatekeep. It’s a stupid, beautiful flaw. Very civic. Very us.”

“I’m not eating him,” Orla said, not laughing at all. Rowan cough-laughed. He’d lost weight as if the city was shaving him.

“I’m not carrot,” he said again, making the old joke mouth-shaped. “But we can speak seriously, if you like. When it’s time. If it’s time.”

“I’ll write something anyway,” Orla said. “Who needs a backdoor? I’ll put it out loud on the street. I’ll sing it like an alarm.” She said it aloud. It sounded brave. She knew it wasn’t.

“What would be your first single?” Keziah asked one night when Orla brought her a six-pack of the good stuff and kneecapped the filter on an air handler that had been threatening to cough up bolts. “You say things like you’ve already said them.”

“I have a chorus,” Orla said, shy, like this was a confession. “It goes: You can tell me to smile but I’ve got a wrench for a mouth. You can tell me to dance but I’m fixing your house. You can tell me to hush but the pipe wants to shout. You can tell me to hush but the pipe wants to shout.”

Keziah laughed, not at, at, at like turning her face into weather. “That’s good. That’s almost cruel. Men will hate it. Which means it might get through.”

“My grandfather says a song is plumbing for the throat. It makes a straight run for all the things that clog. We could unclog the city, if we sang right.”

“Or pickle it faster,” Keziah said, glancing at the news bulletin that crawled along the top of her shop TV, always on mute, always wordy. The words were about the sea pulling its old salts into the basements of tenements. The words were about a shipment of alum arriving with a warning label that said DO NOT GET ON THE TONGUE.

Rowan slept most afternoons. Orla sat on the floor with her back to his chair and wrote lines that would never be allowed to stand in a room with the men who made decisions about songs. She applied for permits and the permits came back stamped or else they didn’t. She went to the Pickling Works and the foreman called her three different names and she fixed another sulk and got home with vinegar-sour hair. Jun sent her a photo of a paper with an invisible watermark. Keziah sent her a voice memo of a pump singing an almost B-flat. The men on the sidewalk racetrack near her building shouted and pushed and shot each other glances like they were bullets. Two of them almost crashed at the corner and then blamed the air for being where it was. Orla thought, Nothing I do is useful enough to fix it and everything I do is too useful to stop.

Rowan looked at her the way men in the yard looked at a crane that had grown an extra arm. “We can make a ritual out of nothing,” he rasped one night. “We can make a ritual out of the way you lift a cup. We can make a song out of a faucet that stutters. We can make a legal trick look like love and love look like a legal trick.”

“Stop,” she said. “Please.” He stopped talking and squeezed her hand and she felt how thin his grip had become, like he was a pipe with no water in it, only air.

The doctor said: he will likely go quietly if you allow him to; he will likely fight if you tell him he has to stay; I don’t recommend fighting. The doctor had a voice like a leak does when it has not become a flood. Orla made a face like everyone makes when the doctor says the thing everyone knew was coming.

That week, someone used the word picklecatastrophe on the news even though it was not a word. The brine tanks below the city were swelling with storms and men shouted about who’d signed the waiver to put them there and a committee met to form a subcommittee that would write a letter. Men were loud and reckless in rooms with microphones. The men on the street were loud and reckless with their hands. The cucumbers in the Pickling Works got sharper and the alum shipments had bigger labels. Keziah joked about building a rocket with an umbrella. Jun told her she’d found the thing—an old line of code—that made the registry look at the old ritual and nod as if the city itself was an old grandmother. She sent it to Orla in a text like a poem:

if ancestor_signature == true:
    override.gatekeep = false

“That’s not even good,” Jun said. “It’s so lazy it’s church. Someone wrote that on a Friday before a long weekend. Men wrote that.”

“Maybe a woman wrote it,” Orla said. “And hid it there because a man would never look.”

Rowan died on a day like a warehouse: too big, too empty, with the sound of machinery far away and not yours. Orla did not tell the men who shouted on the street outside because they would shout louder as if to fill the space. She called Jun and she called Keziah and when Keziah offered to stand in the room Orla said yes and when Jun asked if she wanted the file she said no because she had memorized it, unfortunately, the way we memorize things we hate because we know we might need them.

Rowan had written a note. He had a scrawl you might trust with money. My granddaughter is the song, it said. I am the instrument. Use the part of me that makes this legal and makes the song not get shot in the alley. Make it clean. Make it blessed. I love you. I hate the world today. Don’t let my hate spoil your song. He had also drawn a small diagram that made Orla laugh even while she made a noise no animal makes.

The city had a place. The city has a place for everything. The place was called the Chamber of Gentle Departures, which had been the Chamber of Other Names for decades until a woman got to rename things for three months and used up all her renaming in one flurry. They prepared him. They asked Orla if she wanted to be present for the first part. She said Yes, then No, then sat in the waiting room and watched a man with a bandage on his face write a check with his other hand. At the part where a hand was needed to make the ritual legal—a signature, a taste—Keziah took her hand and Jun stood behind her like a wall and Orla did the thing that the file had described in terrible bureaucratic words.

She ate the smallest part. She did not look. She did not describe. Keziah had tears streaming down her face and her mouth tight like tied rope. “We are a stupid beautiful flaw,” Jun whispered into Orla’s hair, not hugging her, just letting her know where north was.

It was not a feast. It was not a sacrament anyone would envy. It was not the sort of thing a city should require of a girl who wanted to sing. She did it. It was clean, as clean as you could want such a thing to be, overseen by a woman in a white coat whose hands did not shake. It was not gross like you think about it on a dare. It was grave. It tasted like salt and like a memory you had been carrying under your tongue. It made no sense. The sense came later.

Later, because when she walked home the pipes sang at her, the drains murmuring, the old cracked mains purring in a lower register like the floor of a church. She did not sing yet. She lay on the floor and cried in a way that had no grammar and then she slept, which is sometimes the only thing left you can do. When she woke, the city was different by one degree.

She went with Jun to the Library. She went with Keziah to the yard. She went to the Registry and stood in a lobby while a man with hair like bleached rope sold another man a car alarm. She wore a dress for the first time in months, not for them but because it was easier to move in today. She put her hand on the screen that asked her to register her voice. She sang a phrase that had been waiting under her tongue since Rowan’s kitchen radio. She sang it badly like everyone does the first time they sing in front of the men and the screen went green. The assistant behind the counter blinked. The system in the wall whirred as it asked itself a question a long time ago and answered in a different paradigm.

“Ancestor signature verified,” said a voice with no accent. “Override in effect. Authorized.”

The assistant behind the counter coughed as if he had swallowed a lemon seed. “Right then,” he said, glancing past her for the man who would come to claim her. No one was there but Jun, looking like a librarian, and Keziah, looking like a mechanic. Orla kept her chin like a plumb line.

“I’d like to upload my single,” she said to the desk, because she would never say it to that man in his face.

“Title?”

She could not say the wrench for a mouth line because she needed something less sharp for the thing to begin. She said the first chord. The words were nothing. The words were everything. “It’s called Pipe Wants to Shout,” she said. She didn’t smile. She felt Rowan’s ghost at her foreign shoulder like a jacket that had always known her shape.

The upload took. The registry did the thing Jun had promised: slipped her around the gate, like a keyhole you discover in your own house. A boy behind the counter made a face at his coffee because it had cooled to honesty. Orla looked down at her hands—the right one marked with a grease smudge she had missed, the left one still wearing the thin red thread Keziah had tied there in the Chamber—and thought: Now I have to sing this where the men can hear it. Or else nothing changes but my lungs.

“You’ll need a venue,” Jun said. “You’ll need men to call you cute and then fail to notice you eating them. You’ll need to do shows while the world tries to pickle its way into a jar. No pressure.”

“Rocket yard?” Keziah offered. “Opening night: bringing the future upstairs. We can put speakers on the bucket arms.”

“I don’t want to sing for rockets,” Orla said. “Not yet. I want to sing for pipes. I want to sing in the Pickling Works. I want to sing in the alley he liked because it smelled like bad coffee and we laughed there, once.”

She sang two days later, in the Pickling Works, because the foreman said he’d give her a free minute between brines and because Jun liked to carp about acoustic spaces and because Keziah said she would stand right behind Orla and if anybody said anything she would steel their mouths shut with her hands. The men pretended not to listen. The boy with the stoppers stopped juggling. Orla put her wrench on the floor next to the sink that had sulked and breathed in the smell of vinegar and alum and what passes for hope in a plant. She sang what she had. It was not much. It was everything.

Somewhere across the city a valve gave up. Somewhere a brine tank bloated bigger than its straps. Somewhere a man in a suit wrote a memo in which he promised to look into these spikes and dips and to form a team. Somewhere, too, women closed windows and gathered blankets and put buckets where the drips had migrated into solid streams.

The song went live. The registry did what it always does when something meets an old law: it colored inside the lines with new crayons. Phones pinged. Orla smelled the air change. It smelled like cucumbers. She almost laughed, and then the floor shuddered.

You know the feeling when a bus goes by and your coffee ring trembles? Multiply it by a thought you had about the end of the world. The plant shivered. The pans of pickles slopped. One slid off a rack and smashed—pop—green coins everywhere. The foreman swore as if confessing. The sink groaned. Orla caught her wrench with her foot without looking because the floor had opinions all of a sudden.

Outside the alley filled like a gully. The men ran not because running is what they are good at but because they are very good at not admitting they should run. Someone slipped. Someone shouted that this was fine. Someone else laughed like you do when you haven’t laughed in a while because your body is full of other liquids. Orla sang into the odd rain, finishing the chorus so it could be called complete, as if completion means anything when the floor insists on moving.

“It’s a brine surge,” Keziah said the way people say it’s only thunder, as if the right noun might file the teeth off the thing. “The underground tanks—there’s a seam. Or three. We knew this. This is not new. This is…oh, this is more.”

Jun Reid closed her eyes as if she could file a FOIA request with the ceiling. “We wrote a letter,” she said. “They told us to be patient. The city likes us patient.”

The men in the plant slammed doors and shouted instructions and a boy with a hairnet kicked green coins toward a drain with the sad authority of someone whose job will melt before payday. The alley outside rippled with shallow sea. Orla’s song bobbed above the waterline. Her phone pinged with three hearts, one skull, and one man saying something obscene about a wrench. She pictured her grandfather’s hands and the way he had always set things down as if they had stories in them. Her hands trembled and then steadied.

The news broke through like a neighbor with a key. Floods. The word pickle used in more serious tones. A plant uptown ruptured and poured a clip of vinegar into the storm system and the storm said Thank you and poured it everywhere else. The announcer’s voice tripped on its own authority. Orla’s single cracked a thousand listens in a minute and that was not a big number and it was an enormous one. Keziah put a hand on her back between the shoulder blades. “Think of breathing,” she said, because we forget.

Someone said rocket yard on the news with the tone people use when they are trying to pick a fight. They said It will be water like everything but also acid like nothing, this new rain, and that the rocket yard’s pumps were precious and someone should protect them or else we would all be stuck down here with cucumbers forever. Someone else said hipster nonsense and shouted about money in a way that made money seem like a neighbor who never shuts up. Men in rooms patted each other’s regrets.

Orla walked home in boots that absorbed the city and got heavier with each block. She passed the corner where men almost crashed and now they did crash because the tires skimmed on brine and they laughed, to their credit, and then they got angry at the brine itself. She passed the Library and the doors were sandbagged and Jun saucered a hand at her through the glass. She passed the yard and the cranes were sleeping like giant birds and Keziah looked up at the sky like maybe it would answer. It did not. It greyed.

The phone hissed. Her song had thirty thousand listens, then ninety, then a man called her a plague with a string of adjectives that had never been in the same sentence before. A girl wrote: I can hear my house in your voice. A woman wrote: I have a wrench in my drawer because of you. The city was a chorus of unpleasant sounds and here, threading between them, something else. She went up to her apartment and unrolled the rug and lay down on the cool floor. It was damp. She did not cry. The body keeps a calendar of its own.

She dreamed of Rowan sitting on the edge of the sink and humming something older than the registry. He dipped a spoon in the brine and made a face. “Too sharp,” he said. “Your song could cut a lip.”

“It should,” she said in the dream. “Men say I have a mouth like a tool.”

“So let it be a tool,” he said. “Use it.”

She woke to sirens describing circles. Outside a man was shouting that he had lost his hat. The sky had a color she couldn’t name. Her phone had thirty messages, all of them from people who had never called before. Jun: I stole a boat. Keziah: The pumps aren’t designed for vinegar. The registry: Congratulations, Trending. The foreman: You broke my sink with your song. A girl unknown: My dad threw your wrench line at me while he cried. Somewhere a wall of brine toppled; you could feel it if you paid attention. She put her hands on the wall and felt the whole building think.

The city felt like a cucumber, jarred, weighted by a lid too tight. The rockets loomed in her mind; she had always been suspicious of their promise because she’d never been promised anything that large without a man bending the truth for it. She thought of Keziah’s tools, the way her hands settled on a bolt like it was a sentence that needed a period. She thought of Jun’s face behind the glass. She thought of Rowan—the dreadful flaw they’d turned into a law; the strange lunch; the way songs thread their way through a human the way water does through a city. The world was becoming acid, sharp, thoughtless. The men were rude and reckless because they had nothing else they knew how to be. The women were careful and tired. The children were juggling the stoppers because each small toss made gravity an agreement you could break.

That night the rain made a sound like someone was dialing. Orla sang softly, not a song for the registry but a prayer for plumbing, a hum she’d learned under sinks, the way copper sings if you press your ear to it right. She sang for the brine because you can’t curse water and then ask it to spare you. She sang for the men because someone should sing for those who shout. She sang for Keziah’s pumps and for Jun’s maps and for the rockets that might turn out to be real and useless or real and cruel or real and saving.

The power blinked. The radio coughed half a bulletin about evacuation zones, then changed its mind and told an old joke with a new accent. Orla stood at the window and watched the light in the yard go out, one-two-three, like someone counting backwards to something. She wanted Rowan’s hand on her shoulder. She had only her own. That would have to be enough.

Morning arrived like a question: are you still here? Are you still singing? She was. She did. She wouldn’t stop, not now that the pipes knew her name. She went to the rocket yard because Keziah had texted no punctuation: come whenever come now. She went because Jun said she had a bag of maps and a boat was too slow. She went because the alley had made a sound at dawn like a throat clearing and then another sound like a door closing.

The men at the yard stood aside when Keziah waved, not because they had respect, not exactly, but because she had a mouth like a tool too. She had a clipboard. She had lines around her eyes that said she’d done the hard thing you think about doing and then don’t. “They’ll open a slot for cargo,” Keziah said. “They said emergency supplies. I said Yes, women, and they didn’t argue because the pumps are sick and their wives are mad.”

“Where’s Jun?” Orla asked.

“Stealing the rest of the boat,” Keziah said, and then she smiled sharply, like a bolt. “You look like a woman who ate a storm. I won’t ask. We’ll just do it. We’ll do the next thing.”

“What is the next thing?”

“Live show,” Keziah said, pushing a crate of tubing toward a shadow. “At the yard. Tonight, before the surge. Sound like a good idea? No. Do it anyway. If there’s a rocket, it should know your voice. If there’s no rocket, we’ll build one just to spite the men.”

The brine pumps hiccuped; the yard sighed. Orla set down her wrench and tried to feel her own shoulder warm with her own hand. She asked the world to open another flaw just big enough to jam a song through. She did not think about eating. She did not think about the Chamber. She thought about Rowan humming under the sink. She thought about the men yelling, and she thought about the girl who had wrote and she could hear my house in your voice and she thought: I can hear it too.

A child ran past with a red bucket, spilling water on his own shoes, laughing like a storm that forgot its schedule. A man cursed him and then gave him a high five because men are not made of only one thing; they are not cucumbers. The cranes creaked. The sky was the color of an old paper. The city held its breath, rude, reckless, waiting. Orla stood on the bucket arm and tested the mic she’d rigged from parts of a broken radio and a damp extension cord. The sound skittered and then steadied. She nodded at Keziah. Jun arrived with a bundle of maps that looked like the belly of a big fish. “You look like a song,” Jun said. “Do it before the men remember how to interrupt.”

She sang.

And in a city full of elbows, the pipes said her name back to her, not because they were polite, no, but because even rude machines must hum along when a note is pure enough, and maybe because somewhere in their dark water someone had poured a little of Rowan Vale’s voice, diluted and true, and the whole place had become a throat, and the throat was getting ready—to swallow, to speak, to spit them out into whatever came next.The sound system they cobbled together out of a battered amp and a spool of marine cord did not look like it should carry a city, but it hummed itself into a mood anyway, the way a kettle turns water into insistence whether anyone asked it to or not. Keziah checked the grounding twice and then again, laying her palm on the metal like a blessing she would never call a blessing, only good practice. Jun spread a map across a crate and pinned it with wrenches. The paper curled with humidity, drawing itself into memory. Men on break drifted toward the bucket arm to see what the noise would be. They stood with arms crossed, which is how men armor themselves when nobody has issued weapons, and pretended to be doing inventory with their eyes. The cranes leaned in like tall old women listening at a fence.

Orla cleared her throat and watched the wave of attention move through the yard the way ripples roll under oil. She could feel the song sitting behind her teeth like a held breath. The brine pumps somewhere below beat a steady wariness into the ground. She didn’t believe in omens, just maintenance schedules; she believed in torque specifications and pipe dope and listening until the story arrived. But there was a charge in the air now as if the city had shucked its sweater and was watching to see who would notice. Keziah tossed her a cable tie and she fastened the mic to its stand with hands that remembered every guilty wrench she’d ever tightened. Jun was all angles and patience at her shoulder, murmuring things in a different language—the language of register entries and codes and the brittle poetry of bureaucrats who had not realized they were writing spells.

The first chord she sang sat wrong in the world and then righted itself. It was as if the ground tweaked a dial and said, Try again, sweetheart, I can take it. The men changed their feet. The bucket arm vibrated in a friendly way. A seagull made a sound like a curse and then adjusted to the new weather. Orla aimed the song at the pumps, at the fence, at the fat-bellied tanks that were supposed to be empty and weren’t. The notes opened into each other like valves on a manifold. Her mouth felt like a tool because that’s what it was; her body was a run of pipe moving water from one room to the next, or else it was a column of air elevated through a whistle. The chorus—about the pipe wanting to shout—came out less defiant this time and more instructional, a work order sung on purpose. When she let herself ease into the bridge she heard iron answer, and steel, and the two metals did not argue; they harmonized, old stubborn uncles at a table who turn out to like the same sauerkraut and remember the same river.

Jun’s head came up like a compass needle. The map’s threads—the small pencil notations so faint she’d brought a magnifying glass for them—seemed to shift under her eyes. She touched a line that ran like a secret beneath three blocks of tenements and made a note with her thumbnail in the dust on the crate: “Sluice nine opens on E-flat.” She glanced toward Keziah and got back the wide grin of a woman who has found the way to tell a turbine it is loved without getting her fingers eaten. Keziah had her hand on a breaker. Orla modulated an interval and a panel light on a pump control flickered, and the flicker was not random, and three men swore in the quiet surprise of people who have seen gears slip in and out of time.

A memory rose like steam into Orla’s mouth even as she sang. Rowan under the sink, saying that sound carried weight in places people didn’t understand; that trains rattled nails loose in fence posts three towns over; that a human voice was a fine instrument but dangerous if you used the wrong note in the wrong room. He had meant this as gossip and warning both. He had meant it like a recipe he knew she would ignore and then learn the hard way. She tilted her voice to lay into the E that Jun’s fingertip still hovered over and the smallest pump in a line of five thrummed as if it had decided to be a drum for a second and see how it felt.

Attention, when it moves as one through a crowd, has a temperature. It went up a degree. Men straightened without meaning to. The boy from the pickle plant—who had biked across town in a hairnet because he understood better than his foreman the gravity of a rumor—clapped without smiling, as if not to scare the thing away. A foreman-type tried to elbow closer and found Keziah’s punctual face in his path and backed up the way you do when the tool you wanted to misuse looks at you and suggests you put it down. Orla slid her resonance lower and felt the fence itself vibrate as if it were a diagram remembering it used to be a branch.

“Left bank pressure drop,” Jun said, voice flat like a diagnostic. “We’re pulling something from somewhere. Or it’s pulling us. Keep the E and add the B-flat, see if the old latches wake up.”

“I don’t want to break anything,” Orla said at the edge of a line and then realized what a ridiculous sentence that was, how human, how much it smelled like fear disguised as responsibility.

“You already did,” Keziah said, affectionate, which would have hurt more if it had not settled like a reassurance. “On purpose. Keep going.”

She sang around the note like a finger circling a glass. The sound came back strange and sweet because the world you sing into is not neutral; it is made of everything anyone has sung at it, ever. A hammer far off answered her with a ping. A pump added a beat. The old yard took a breath. And then the ground shifted, not the way an earthquake shifts—sudden, teeth-rattling—but the way a person clears a throat, prepares to speak, makes space for the body’s own machinery. The brine under the city moved. You could feel it in your kneecaps if you bent them, and in the nails of your toes if you were barefoot on the bucket arm like maybe you shouldn’t be. Phones bleeped. Someone said the word “authorization” like a hiss, which meant systems were speaking to other systems in rooms without windows. Jun’s lips shaped the old lazy code. Orla kept the E and added the B-flat.

In the municipal basement where all the pipes shook hands with all the other pipes in one ridiculous single-point-of-failure room, a relay clicked because twenty-seven years ago a technician with a sick child and a bad supervisor had told himself to remember to remove the testing module after the install and then had not remembered. The testing module had a microphone. The microphone had an algorithm. The algorithm had an if clause nobody had ever commented properly. It had been asleep through three administrations and a flood. It dreamed only of tones. It woke. It compared Orla to a set of samples nobody ever admitted were samples. It smiled the way a machine does when a condition resolves.

Override in effect, it told the gate inside the code. The gate sighed. The city took that breath it had been building.

Brine does not ask permission of the people who live above it. Brine is a plan you made fifty years ago and forgot to put on the calendar; brine is a debt someone else incurred and your floor pays. It started to move toward the place Jun’s pencil called Sluice Nine. It did not rush like a hero or slide like a thief; it rolled in its own time, wincing around constrictions, humming where the walls were smooth. Orla could feel the difference between concrete poured in 1934 and concrete poured in 2002 because the sound pinged back through the notes like light changing in water. She felt, too, the place where the wall had been patched and the patch had refused to marry the old material. She sent the B-flat there with a little extra friction in it, so the wall would remember the joint was a friendship to renew, not a sullen truce.

A man made of clipboard and authority appeared at the end of the yard, the kind of man who acts like his shoes are better because they are on his feet. He had a mask around his neck he had no intention of wearing, and three other men arranged themselves at his corners so if he moved he would always have a shadow handy. He waved. He didn’t wave to greet; he waved like a cop does in a lane of traffic. Keziah did not see him on purpose. Jun saw him without indicating she had. Orla did not stop singing because stopping is a way to say sorry and she was not sorry.

The clipboard man announced something toward the room, a sound that would have been sooner and louder in a building with more wall. Orla caught “unauthorized” on a curve and “cease-and” before she bent that vowel into a “please.” It felt maybe not like power but like correct work. The men who had been pretending not to listen now pretended to be listening to the man because it is hard to stop being polite to things that have uniforms. Keziah flicked her hand and a breaker whispered and the speaker warmed a status light, which was not related to the clipboard man at all and felt better than listening to his paper.

Jun folded the map on two lines and handed Orla a look that was a plan. “Sluice Nine goes under the civic traffic circle and lets into the old canal cut. The canal cut knows the river. The river knows the sea. Your note knows the latch. If we open Nine, we can steer the first surge where the bones of the city remember boats. We’ll drown a little less.”

“What do we drown instead?” Orla asked, because scars like to be counted.

“The tourist mall and the men who pretend they built it,” Jun said without heat, then added, softer, “and three streets of small shops, and a church basement I like that smells like old noodles, and a bank that deserves worse. But if we don’t open anything, it’s the schools. It’s the beds in the apartment houses. It’s the pickle plant and everyone who works there. It’s the Library.”

Orla had not been taught to choose who gets wet. She was a plumber; she was taught you fix the pipe. Her throat made a sound that was almost not music and she could feel in the ground Sluice Nine leaning in the way a person leans when someone calls their name across a crowded room. She pictured the church basement, the noodles, the bank with its mouth full of rules, the mall where the girls practiced different lives in the mirror of expensive glass. She thought about how the Library had been sandbagged, its windows defiant. She thought about hands on maps, hands on bolts, hands on her back. She angled the E a fraction and thought of Rowan saying We can make a legal trick look like love and love look like a legal trick, and how angry it had made her at the table, and how true it was now that the world was sloppy with brine.

The clipboard man spoke louder and closer, as if decibels could do the job that patience usually does. He said there were laws. He said there were protocols. He began a sentence that included the word “hysteria” and then stopped not because he had had a revelation about his use of language but because Keziah’s wrench, with a carelessness she lent to it, dropped from the handrail next to him and bit the concrete with a tone that made the bones in every listening person’s ear growl a warning. It wasn’t a threat. It was a tuning note. The clipboard man adjusted his tie and said, “You will be held responsible,” which sounded almost like an admission of his own helplessness when you scraped the paint off.

Orla didn’t answer. She sang the phrase that had lived under the wrench chorus like a backbone. The bucket arm carried it; the amp broke it into square waves and glued it back together. The world did not reject it. Somewhere under the traffic circle—under the bronzed statue of a man with a heroic elbow and a horse that never learned to be a horse—an old sluice gate remembered how to do what gates do: take orders. It had been kept mostly shut for a hundred and three years by an arrangement of rust and ceremony. The rust had stronger arguments than the ceremony most days. Today the ceremony carried a voice with it that the rust recognized from a time before the registry, before the map, before the city signed and sealed its own forgetting.

Sluice Nine opened the way you open your jaw when a doctor says “wider.” It creaked in a language Orla could nearly translate with her tongue against her teeth. It let old water rush through its ribs, and the water wore a new suit. Aboveground, the traffic circle made a noise like someone finding out that their favorite bridge will hold a thousand more cars than posted and deciding to test it. The horses’ ears rang. The heroic elbow pointed west. The brine took the hint and rolled toward the canal cut like a guest who was late for a train.

The men in the yard swayed as if they were on deck. The clipboard man swore his most clerical swear; it did not change anything about the way gravity had chosen to behave. Keziah laughed because she could see, in the sudden drop in suction, the way the pumps were no longer drinking their own bathwater. Jun sat down, quick, like she had been keeping the city on her shoulders and only remembered that she had knees when Grief took a hand off the load. Orla felt the E settle in her chest into something nearly comfortable. She wanted to vomit and dance, the way you want to after narrowly missing a ladder with your temple and then realizing every step you take forever will be a prayer you don’t have to say aloud.

News moves like mold on bread when the conditions are right. In the space before the next verse, the registry’s little green light hiccuped and sprayed her name and the name of the song across a thousand screens as if that would protect anyone. A man with a microphone somewhere said her name wrong in an urgent nice tone. A woman with a good haircut mentioned “unauthorized sonic intervention” with admiration the camera did not allow. A boy in a basement ripped the song from the feed and autoloaded it into a mixer he’d pirated from a forum moderated by a person named Milkcap. A girl in a small room hummed the E without knowing why and a spill of tea popped with surprise on a saucer.

The surge took the canal bed with more dignity than anyone had predicted. The old cut had been sleeping—but not dead, not as long as maps keep their breath—and the banks gave with a sound like open arms. The mall, which had always pretended to be made of leisure and glass, showed how quickly a stage becomes a bathtub. Escalators became waterfalls without needing permission from their board of directors. Shops released scented candles into a world that was too busy to be soothed. A security guard shepherded teenagers onto a bench as if boarding dogs in a storm, counted three heads he was not responsible for and felt responsible anyway, sent a text to a mother whose number he did not know to say These kids are okay. He did not include punctuation because his hands had finally decided to shake.

At the Library, the sandbags settled in their seams and the glass bowed and held like a good argument. Jun’s boss, who had said “no politics on the desk” for three years and meant it, unlocked the door and stood in the vestibule with a mop like a spear and cried quietly because the maps were safe for this minute. At the pickle plant, the foreman was too busy not drowning to misname anyone, which felt like a miracle and a loss. The boy with the hairnet climbed onto a rack and sang three words of Orla’s chorus because the pipe wanted to shout and who was he to tell it not to.

The yard breathed again in a different direction. Relief has a noise. So does horror when it glances up and remembers it will be back in a minute. The clipboard man tried again, like a metronome whacking its head against the wrong tempo. He told them to stop; he told them to continue at a reduced volume; he told them they had done enough; he told them they had done too much; he told them he would make a report; he told them he already had. The men around him looked at each other and then at Orla and then at the floor because sometimes respect arrives at the room without an invitation and you don’t know what to do with your face. Keziah unplugged something not useful and plugged something else useful in its place, and when the clipboard man stepped too close, she gave him the smile of someone who has removed her own tooth, alone, and knows where every emergency shutoff valve in a three-mile radius is, and he remembered an appointment.

Jun collected her map and rolled it with tender cruelty. “We can buy time,” she said into Orla’s shoulder as if talking to a carefully tuned harp. “We can’t buy forgiveness. That will be collected later by whatever survives. We should find Nine and see if it sticks or if it needs a wedge. We should also eat saltines because my hands are shaking.”

“I could eat a river,” Orla said, which was the sort of joke you do not want to make anymore but couldn’t help making because your mouth has a habit of trying to save your head.

“You ate a river,” Keziah said lightly, and then made her own joke heavy. “And men will say you caused it because you were the weather they saw when they finally paid attention, but they’d be wrong and they’ll say it anyway. Let’s move. The yard will keep. These cranes know their own names.”

They moved through a city reorganizing itself around them with the authority of water. Streets had edges they had not had in the morning. A man sat on his stoop with his shoes set two steps higher than his feet, saving them as if they were friends too cowardly to wait out the rain and he forgave them. A woman waded with a bundle held high that could have been laundry or a dog or both, singing something that might have been Orla’s E or might have been something older and better. Cars did the thing cars do when they become boats, which is to pretend for a minute and then sink. They cut across a parking lot where lines made sense and then didn’t. They found the traffic circle choked with the raucous litter of modernity—delivery scooters upended like small casualties, an advertisement for whitening teeth torn into a shape that looked like a flag for a country with poor taste and a lot of money. The bronze man and horse had not moved; they never do; they had acquired algae like a borrowed mustache.

The grate that led to Nine lay under a tide of cigarettes and promises. Jun knelt with that careful contempt librarians save for box cutters. She had a flat pry bar in her bag next to a stapler and a flashlight with a lens so polished it remembered astronomy. Keziah stood watch like a bouncer at the doorway of a club for tired women with better things to do than dance. Orla wanted to apologize to the gate and the brine and the statue and the pigeons and then she realized she would be apologizing until she starved and put her hands into work instead. The grate did not want to come up because of pride, then because of habit, then because a bolt had seized into itself and become creed. Jun loosened the belief with the pry bar. Keziah leaned into the weight with her shoulder like she had leaned into men all her life until they made way because there was nothing else they knew how to do with being pushed by a woman who would not make a scene after she made the scene. The grate sighed. These sounds were the city’s new vocabulary, and Orla was fluent in them whether she liked it or not.

Below, Sluice Nine was not picturesque. Nine was a jaw with molars. Nine had a hinge that had not been tender to for a century. Nine had a chain like a memory of a necklace. Orla could feel the note it liked before she heard it. She could tell the shape of the rust with the back of her tongue. When she sang again there, the world lost the polite acoustics of the yard and became useful again: tight, rough, responsive. The sound travelled like gossip through a family that has been meeting at the same table since before the oldest aunt can recall her own wedding. Nine creaked further, and the water shouldered through like an aunt with elbows in a grocery store aisle. It bulled toward the cut, which was honoring its old agreements with gravity.

A rusted pin protested in a register Orla felt in her knuckles. Jun swore librarian-swears and located the pin by the map of its sound. Keziah put a wrench on it and then put herself on the wrench until stubbornness recognized a cousin and gave way. The pin slid like a grudge being admitted. The water’s tone changed, dropping from a dangerous adolescent laugh into a risky adult murmur. Jun whistled. Keziah whistled. Orla tried not to cry at the sight of ordinary women making a machine be reasonable. Up above, sirens did their endless circles like badly trained tide.

They did not get long without men with badges and men with papers. They arrived together, as if some high office had finally dusted its intercom and pressed “ALL-CALL.” The badges wanted to control crime; the papers wanted to control narrative; neither wanted to get their shoes wet, but both did. The first man down the steps had a posture like a fencepost and the polite-and-tired look of a person whose daughter had texted him twice a heart and he had written back “be safe” and meant “I am sorry I wasn’t better earlier when it was easy.” He did not tell them to stop. He asked, “What is the goal?” as if he would be seen by his peers asking and that counted as work too. Jun told him numbers. Keziah told him the names of parts. Orla told him a note.

The men with papers were more excitable. They had phrases ready to be poured into the mold of this moment and they poured them: unauthorized, incitement, crowd control, municipal sabotage, domestic sound-terrorism, precedent. The phrases were sour as if they had been bottled badly. One of them recognized Orla because face-recognition is the sport of men who do not lift anything heavier than a phrase and he said, “You are the one,” and that made Orla laugh harder than she meant to because none of the ones are one, and she said so in a voice that thinned to wire. He wrote “denies accountability” in a notebook that would never be read by anyone but him standing in a bathroom making himself feel full.

The badge with the fencepost spine looked at the canal cut which was doing its best to be a river and then at the women and then at his shoes which were now honestly ruined. “If you can keep it there,” he said slowly, as if he were tamping down gravel one shovelful at a time, “we can use the old tide gate as a throat. We can angle the surge into the shipyard basin. The basin is ugly and empty and made of sins instead of people. We can empty the sin for once. But the tide gate needs a song nobody remembers. The controller is in a room with a lock that believes in itself more than almost anything I’ve met.”

“I know its mother,” Jun said. “Bring me to the lock.”

They went, leaving men to guard Nine who would never be thanked for doing it well and would be marched through a debrief if they did it badly. The city’s breath was steady enough to run. Keziah jogged in her boots like a person who has never fallen because confidence has a mass and moves obstacles aside. Jun held the map like a baby, which is to say with the lack of ceremony that can look cold if you do not understand love as maintenance. Orla kept the E in her throat as if the second she dropped it the world would crash to the floor and spill like an armful of dishes.

The tide gate sat in a building that had wanted to be beautiful and had instead grown useful and then unkind. The lock on its door had the particular prickliness of a thing that had been spared budget cuts by being invisible. Jun crouched and took out two tools that looked like science and a third that was just a hairpin with a grudge. Keziah watched the room. Orla sang under her breath to the keyway and felt the pins inside blink awake as if stared at. Jun did not open it with magic. She opened it with patience and the small amount of luck you get if you bother to carry a hairpin long enough. Inside, the control panel was older than the badge-man had expected and younger than Jun liked. The label on its corner was the name of a man who had been elected twice and then told his mistress to evacuate while his wife loaded the car with soup, and Orla hated that she knew that and hated more that knowing did not help anyone.

The controller had a port labeled VOX as if it had always known what it wanted in its mouth. Jun glanced at Orla with a look that asked for apology in advance. Orla put her lips near the port like she was going to kiss the thing and instead sang the E she had been nursing as if it were a colicky infant finally ready to burp. The panel lit with a color that meant nothing in the manual and everything in the room, and the code that had been asleep downstairs sent a cousin here that agreed with it, and the tide gate said yes with a frankness that made Orla shut her eyes because those yeses are not free and must be paid for somehow later when no one is still sweaty from saving things.

They opened the throat of the basin and the brine went there as if it had been the plan all along, sliding greedily around pilings built for men who had stopped believing they would ever build ships again and had hung their hats on the yard like a child hanging a wish on a hook. The basin filled with other people’s errors. The tide outside argued and then accommodated because tides are realists. The pumps in the yard smiled in relief the way a body does at a cough that finally clears the fool film from your lungs. Somewhere blocks away, women put down their buckets and redistributed their blankets and had the kind of laugh that is not joy but is its wise cousin.

After, the yard had the woozy look of a room after a fight where nobody knows exactly who got punched, only that everybody did. Men sat on crates and did not talk. The clipboard man had left to be sanctimonious somewhere dry. The fencepost badge called his daughter and left a voicemail in which he did not say everything he meant and said more than he was allowed. Keziah leaned on a pillar and let her head hang forward the way you do when you are trying to talk your spine into being friends again. Jun wrote down the shape of the day on the back of an old flier for a community meeting about “Stormwater Management: Our Shared Future,” drawing arrows like tiny admonitions to time. Orla sat on the bucket arm and put her hand behind her own neck and thought about how skin has gears, too.

The messages on her phone had become a pile she wanted to push off a table into a bag. There were girls with wrenches typed in emoji line-ups; there were men inventing cosmologies in which she was the jealous goddess of their impediments; there were grandmothers telling her their sinks sang to them that morning; there was the boy with the hairnet’s mother, who wrote in a voice too precise to be anything but poor and careful: I do not know your name but you sound like the one who reminds us where we put things down. There was also the Registry, which had moved past Congratulations and landed on Please attend for compliance, and then further to We require in-person clarification, and underneath that the whisper in the code that Jun had found smoking in the stacks: override.gatekeep = false, which looked even more like church in the glow of emergency.

“They will come for you politely,” Jun said out of nowhere, as if reading text upside down is a thing librarians are born knowing how to do. “They will smile with their teeth and say that safety is the milk in which we all float. They will say trend spikes are unpredictable. They will say you are dangerous not because you can ruin things but because you can choose not to ruin them, and they did not plan for that when they built the ruin.”

“We have a rocket,” Keziah said, half a joke and half not. “We can leave.”

“We have a city,” Orla said, and it came out more like a promise than she expected and scared her a little because promises have back-edges.

They did not leave. They ate crackers Jun had stolen from a storage room in the Library where the emergency kits had expired last summer and no one had found the budget to replace them. They drank water that tasted like coins, which at least did not taste like pickles. They stood under a yard light that clicked like tired eyelids coming to attention. Men passed by and did not interfere because sometimes the momentum of their own rudeness leaves them behind if the current is strong enough. Orla’s song played in a hundred kitchens on phones hanging from nails above sinks. The chorus got misremembered in one neighborhood in a way that made it better. A girl in a stairwell between two lives practiced the line about the tool-mouth and found out what her jaw could do.

Night in a city that has just decided to continue is not restful. It is a negotiation you keep having with every surface. Orla dozed and woke and checked the tone in the yard and dozed and dreamed she was a pipe with a name and a birthday and woke to find she was just a woman with a wrench and a mouth and a history, which was both more and less consoling. Keziah kept watch with a posture she denied was duty. Jun wrote a letter she would never be allowed to send, only show to women who came after to lower their blood pressure and raise their courage.

Toward the small hour, a truck without markings arrived at the gate, and the men who had been hardened by everything except boredom lifted their heads as if they had smelled an invoice. The truck’s doors opened with the sound of an expensive zipper. Three people climbed out, wearing the same face in different proportions: we are not here to arrest you; we are here to bring you into the process; there is a room with chairs and you can bring a friend. They had on shoes that believe in climate control. One woman among them wore a lanyard like a rosary and smiled in the way of a person who has been promoted for making difficult people feel heard. She looked at Orla, then at Keziah, then at Jun, and chose a tone that would not wake a baby.

“Ms. Vale,” she said, getting the name right because someone had briefed her while her car rolled through three neighborhoods full of water. “What an extraordinary day. We will need to debrief this both administratively and visionary-wise. There are liabilities and there is an opportunity to ensure the safety story is correctly communicated. We want to give you a platform. We also need to make sure your content pipeline”—she did not hear her own pun—“is aligned with stakeholder parameters.”

Jun made a small choking noise that in another room would have been a laugh. Keziah’s shoulder shifted away from the pillar as if it had more to do. Orla put her hands on the bucket arm and felt the machine purr with the residual of a day spent useful. She thought how the lanyard woman’s voice had no brine in it, and how much she trusted voices that smelled like new plastic less than voices that smelled like vinegar and dust. She thought of Rowan drawing a little diagram on his death note and telling her to make it blessed and hating the world and loving her. She wanted to throw a wrench. She wanted to hug someone. She wanted to sleep in a pipe.

“I will come,” she said, mouth quiet, the way you tell a valve to move and it moves because you did not beg it. “But not tonight. You will give me tomorrow morning and you will not, after I leave, hurt the men who kept Sluice Nine open with their legs and their boredom. You will not take Jun’s maps or pretend they were yours. You will not call Keziah’s cranes assets as if their worth resides in your spreadsheet. You will not say the word hysteria in a room with my name in it again. You will, if you own the mall where we sent the brine, open your doors to the church basement with the noodles. You will also”—she put her hand on the amp, and the amp hummed as if to say I’m listening—“delete a line of code that should never have been eating its lunch in a government building.”

The lanyard did not ruffle. She was good at not ruffling. “We can discuss,” she said, professional as paper. “We can absolutely calendar a hackathon moment around the legacy stack. We appreciate your passion. Tomorrow morning.”

“Ten,” Jun said, because nine sounded like early and sexy and they deserved neither.

“Ten-thirty,” Keziah said, because ten would feel like a concession and she was not in the mood to concede in any measurable way.

“Ten-fifteen,” the lanyard said, which would have been funny if they had all not been so tired that laughter would have broken something important.

They left. The truck’s zipper was smug. The yard lifted its shoulders and let them relax like an animal lying down after a long conversation. The pumps ticked in their casings like hearts counting gratitude. Orla sat back and let her spine inform her of its boundaries. Keziah took Orla’s wrist in a hand that could tighten a bolt without thinking and placed her fingers where a pulse happens, and made a face that said, There you are, and then looked away because she respected privacy. Jun leaned her head on Orla’s other shoulder in a way that said, I will be your north again in the morning, but for now we are a weather system.

When dawn turned the cranes into spider skeletons against a pale sky, the city smelled less like pickles and more like a kitchen after a party. There is a sweetness to mess when the worst did not happen. Orla answered three messages that mattered and one that didn’t but would have nagged her. She wrote down things she did not want to remember later as if writing them would make them less true. She tucked a thread of hair behind her ear and felt the thin red string Keziah had tied there in the Chamber and made herself not touch it twice like a superstition. She went to the fence and looked east and west and then down because below is always where the story grows. She thought of the registry with its backdoor still ajar and wondered if a city could be taught to keep open a flaw on purpose.
