Some people wanted to call her a saint of pipes and some wanted to call her a cannibal of legacy and some wanted to call her on the phone and ironically they had better words than that. It is hard to let private things be private when they are public infrastructure. Orla refused interviews that wanted the recipe and accepted conversations from women who needed to know how to make a door that would open for all the girls behind them and not slam shut on their own hand.

Jun did what Jun does: she wrote down the problem until it had to be honest and then she found legal paper that didn’t ask permission to exist. She drafted a license on Library time that began, Songs as Infrastructure: A Civic Commons, and under it put sentences so plain the men kept looking for the trick. The license said you could not own a voice that turned the water from harm to not, even if you attached it to a platform and a lanyard and five subcommittees. It said downloads were for survival and also joy. It said if you built a gate you had to count how many people liked it, not how many people you kept out. It said nothing about ghosts, because Jun knew that if you write a door in law for a ghost the wrong men walk through it and sell the hinges. The clerk with the grandmother in the noodle church stamped it and went home on a bus that hummed under him and told his cousin everything.

Orla did not write a song about the Chamber and her mouth and the smallest part because there are things you do not turn into rhyme and sell back to yourself. She wrote a verse about inheritance that called it soup and not blood and put into it a line Rowan would have hated and loved: we cooked our dead into instructions the way you cook a bone until it lets go. She put that line in her pocket and did not sing it yet. She did not need to; the pipes hummed that sentiment in a crude way when they remembered who they were carrying for, and the aunties corrected them at the end of each phrase.

While the city argued itself into enlightenment and then out again on the hour, water continued to behave as always. A facility upriver spat a breath of something not labeled properly and the water licked its teeth. Keziah found a little pitting on a vane and kissed her teeth and Orla made the choir hold a discord long enough to convince a pump that cavitation was a life choice it could skip. The Listening that had felt like an experiment turned regular the way a dinner that happens twice in a row turns into a tradition if you have the nerve to call it one. Sluice Seven got jealous in a way only a gate can and they cajoled it with a note it remembered from 1912 when a woman whose name never made it into any book had tapped it with a ladle during a breach and told it to behave because she had six kids and five pots and no room for this.

The registry kept trying to mitt Orla into safe lanes. It suggested collaboration with a brand. It offered to put her face on a poster with a child wearing noise-cancelers and a tagline about decibels and duty. It pitched a line of licensed wrenches that would spark joy without sparking anything dangerous. When she did not answer, the registry sent the lanyard with a smile that was a better fence than any; it asked again to be allowed to put her in front of a board that had discovered it could be generous at scale with other people’s gusts. Orla said she would stand in front of any board that would sit in front of Sluice Nine for three hours and write down what it learned about patience. There were no takers and there were three shocked sighs, which felt like a good day’s tally.

Mercy in a city arrives in sneaky places. A laundromat on Ninth whose owner had been fined twice for refusing to install a television and once for cooking beans in the back let the Listening dry their damp hanging baffles for free and made every child leave with two mismatched socks on purpose like a game to remind them they had been somewhere they were part of the machinery. The Pickling Works, having considered its sharpness and found it wanting, went back to its old recipes for a week and the men pretended not to notice and then sighed like a crowd remembering their first honest meal in a season. The church basement’s noodles tasted more like soup and less like damp cardboard, and the pastor had the nerve to ask Orla to fix a toilet afterward because the Lord does not despise small labor and because salvation is passive voice for help me carry this bucket.

The men who had organized their horns into a chord showed up at the yard with a sheepish box of donuts and wanted very much to talk about engines. One of them, whose watch remembered better times, said without a joke that he was tired of being a person who only learned to push and wanted to learn to pull. Keziah handed him a length of line and pointed at a chain that had been sulking under its own rust; he pulled until it moved and made a face like a man experiencing opinion where muscle had been, and laughed in a way that suggested he might bring lunch next time on purpose.

On the second Tuesday after the static fire, a rumor exactly the size of a window slithered into the yard with the same energy. The men with dry shoes had found money to write a date for a launch the way you write a name in icing on a cake, not because the cake needs sweet to be cake but because it looks good in photographs. The basin was behaving like a friend who had finally learned to say no to late-night calls and might not always pick up. The brine had subsided to a level that made the clipboard men stand taller and the aunties cock their heads. A day with less water is a day when men forget to be grateful and start deciding again without asking, and you could feel that arrogance slide back into the room like a shadow under a door.

Orla could have said no to being at the yard that day, but saying no to noises she wanted to shape felt like letting someone else tune a pipe with a hammer. She said yes to Keziah with her eyes. Jun pretended to be needed by three committees at once and in the gaps brought them a bag of bolts and a list of ward captains who had called to say that if anyone suggested a celebratory horn parade they would throw shoes.

The morning of the window smelled like cardboard and concentrate. Men ran their hands down their shirts twice before a camera saw them; women tucked two extra bandanas into back pockets like talismans. Over the basin the air looked normal, which is to say treacherous and probable. The crowd by the fence did not gather like a mob but like neighbors whose leases had been rewritten without them and were curious who had signed their names. The lanyard woman stood under a new hard hat that had a sticker on it with a logo adjusted to match the color of the sky. The badge with the fencepost spine had once again become the person whose yes would be carved in blame if things became no.

Keziah’s hands were steady and therefore her voice could afford trembling. “Everyone who matters is here,” she said toward the rail and maybe toward Orla, then to the pumps in a tone she used for bolts that would strip if you used the wrong wrench. “Do your jobs. Do not show off. I am very tired.”

The first flame was theatre, the second a statement. The machine bit down into the bolts it had chosen; the air lifted its elbows; the water in the basin clenched and then kept being water. For a minute, the roar settled into a steady insistence and each person in the yard remembered a different person they loved, which is what big noise does; it wipes the slate and puts a picture back in a corner out of nowhere. Orla sang and was mostly singing to the inside of her own head, but things inside her head had learned how to go places.

The tremor came different than static. It wasn’t upward; it wasn’t down. It was a side to side like a child’s first wrong step, a hint of pogo nobody had scheduled because the math for that had been done, signed, filed. Men who trusted math looked around as if to find the person they could accuse of rounding. Keziah’s jaw made a list. Jun’s pencil snapped and she took it as a sign to use her voice and called, A-sharp, blunt, and Orla grinned because the aunties had named that note stubborn and the names were the same thing today. She sent the A-sharp and felt it take a bite out of the tremor like a good dog at a bad ankle. The containers were not enough; she saw the odd bounce on a midspan brace and hated the engineer who had chosen cost over calm and sent him forgiveness in a chord, because you have to forgive the dead who built the living you hate, or live bitter in a room full of pipes you will never listen to right.

Someone at the fence shouted come down because they thought she would be safer closer to the ground, and Orla thought for a cold second of falling, and then thought, Safety is such a liar when it is trying to hide control, and stayed where her mouth could aim. The tremor tried to climb anyway the way ivy does when you swear you cut it to nothing. She found the space in the back of her throat where Rowan had kept the sound he used to scold a leaking trap without waking the house, and she put the house to sleep with it. There is a note you can sing that is not music and is still mercy; it tells metal you remember what it wants to be on a day when everyone asks it to be other. The pogo wavered. The basin did its ancient job again with the patience of geology. The machine remembered to be muscle and not mouth.

If the city cheered, it did it in private between girders. In public, it took off its hat and put it on and took it off again and pretended it was not crying at its own wrist. The men whose horns had joined the chord last time made no sound. The lanyard woman put a line through a word on a page no one would see and wrote the same word again in a letter two days later and called it leadership. A child by the fence, scolded for not covering ears, covered eyes instead and bragged later to a cousin that it had been louder that way, which was true enough to keep.

After, under the shadow of a crane that thought it was a bird when it was very tired, Orla leaned against hot steel and said to nobody she could name, “I cannot be the hinge forever,” and Keziah, who had not been listening because she had been relighting the furnace of her own heart, said, “Good, because I like doors but I love walls that hold.” Jun arrived with a thermos of coffee that tasted like ocean and blame and set it between them. They drank without letting their mouths touch the lid because certain intimacies are for other days and because the yard had eyes. A man walked by and didn’t say thank you and for once it did not take anything from the room to let him keep his silence.

In the week that followed, the city found its appetite for ordinary again. It argued about parking and our lady of the basilica’s new paint and whether the market should allow a pop-up selling kombucha pronounced wrong. It put bubble wrap around the places where the brine had made edges and let kids pop the bubbles without telling them what they represented. It made the aunties saints in two neighborhoods where men did not usually admit sainthood came with a haircut and a grocery list. The Registry issued a press release that sounded like a marriage proposal written by a committee and addressed to a person who had already eloped. Orla fixed a skittish check valve in an old walk-up and a boy showed her a frog he had rescued from a puddle that was too sharp and she bit her mouth because it was a decent thing to do and because there is never enough decency but sometimes there is exactly one frog at the right time.

The other rumor on the wind wore different shoes. You could hear it in the courthouse corridor where men with memory loss in their eyes looked at women carrying copies of records like knives. You could hear it in the supply room at the yard where someone wrote on a white board in dry erase paint that was never meant to erase DECIBEL CREDIT BANK and then changed the subject when Keziah walked in. You could hear it in the Library stacks where Jun found a budget draft that suggested the Listening be brought indoors under the auspices of Men With Permission and moved to Thursdays. There is always a rumor that wants to turn songs into permits. Jun rolled the draft into a tube and slid it under the leg of a table that wobbled and called that governance, and laughed alone, the brittle laughter of someone who has managed to be promoted into a position where she can be fired publicly for being right.

At night in Orla’s apartment the pipes had begun to speak with an authority that was not Rowan’s. His voice was in there, kind as an old screw head that had seen the right screwdriver; his laugh made the elbow in the bathroom never complain even when the building shivered. But something else had moved into the throat of the walls, something older than the registry and younger than the bricks. It came like a bassline through the hot water riser, steady, curious, not asking permission to exist. It asked her for nothing but attention and delivered nothing but request. She found that if she put her bare feet on the tile and her head against the plaster where the pipe elbowed through, she could hear it almost speak. The city, if you want to name it, had decided to use her for a mouth for one thing only: its need to be called by a name she had not thought to ask it for.

She outlasted the urge to hold a ceremony for that. There are so many ceremonies waiting for women who have done anything even slightly strange; you can lose your entire life to them and die without ever doing the work again. She sat with her back against the wall and thought about the first time she had held a chase nipple in her small hand and felt the joy of a piece of metal that knew its job. She thought about the day the men invented a word that did not exist—picklecatastrophe—and how quickly it had become a tool they shook at each other when they forgot what problem they had actually made. She thought about Keziah’s hand finding her waist without asking for permission in a moment when permission was noise, not safety, and finding that she had saved herself an answer by not falling. She thought about Jun’s laugh in bureaucrat rooms and how it had become a fulcrum.

When sleep came, it brought Rowan and something else, a river mouth with a voice like sand and a laugh like a bell in a fog. The dream had the taste of metal, which meant her body had decided to be honest. The river mouth said, without moving, You are not the hinge, girl, you are a bolt. Bolts are not heroes, and bolts are not poets, but the world falls apart at the failure of the humble, and heroes and poets alike go through. She woke up angry for half a second at the demotion and then hungry in the way a person is when called to labor instead of applause. On the radio, the anchor had learned to distinguish between weather and consequences and had begun, cautiously, to tell the difference in his sentences.

At the Listening that Thursday, which no committee could reschedule no matter how they moved the boxes on their forms, the aunties sang the A-sharp with the swagger of women who had saved a school from a wet rug and knew it. The teenagers added a blue note they had no right to and everyone forgave them because the world would always need something rude to pull it forward. Orla taught a new line about a door that had been painted shut and how paint remembers being sky if you unteach it. The pipes obeyed, which is to say they argued in an orderly fashion and then did. In the back, a girl with a wrench on her shoulder drawn in crayon on her shirt elbowed a boy who had learned to juggle without dropping anything and said, It sounds like our house, and he said, It is our house, in a tone that sounded like a promise pretending to be a simple fact so it could live.

The launch window narrowed then widened then narrowed because men negotiate with sky like they negotiate with each other, repeating their names until one of them sticks to a wall. The basin held with dignity and demanded its due. The registry discovered, to its dismay and secret delight, that a commons license is cheaper than a war. The lanyard woman adjusted to the idea of being the person who got the right things wrong in public and wore her new mistakes with a competence that finally let her take off her smile. The clipboard men evolved into safety men into operations men into men who did not need to be told twice which direction the brine will prefer; evolution is expensive when you have shoes you love.

On the morning the window narrowed enough to truth and everybody knew it without being told, Jun appeared in Orla’s doorway with a bag of bolts, a map, an apple, and a look that said something had been waiting in a stack too long and had finally stretched its legs. “They will do it today,” she said, and her face did not decide whether to be hope or the other thing. “This isn’t a speech. This isn’t a fight. This is a ride. He would have hated it,” and Rowan’s name did not have to be spoken because the pipe down the hall made a sympathetic sound like a saint being reminded of a sin they had chosen on purpose.

“Then we will sing,” Orla said, and Keziah’s knock on the door meant they didn’t have time to sit with the brutal plainness of that and they would carry it with them anyway like a wrench you don’t use but need because your hand is used to its weight. The yard had eyes like a person waiting for a diagnosis. The basin had been combed in a deliberate way that made men feel they had asked gravity to sign permission slips. The horns at the fence were quiet, their men having learned from the last time that sometimes participating is pointing and sometimes it is not doing that.

If the city had a name other than the one on maps it did not say it. If the city had a song other than the ones we give it daily by living in it, it did not sing it. It hummed though, a hum in ducts and ribs and old wood and the seam where carpet meets tile. Orla stood where her mouth did a job bolts cannot and let herself carry all the ordinary heavy little things she would carry in any case because glamour is a liar and work is also a liar and together they make something close enough to honest to hold while the sky tests the math and the man at the microphone remembers to say the number only once.

The flame came and the noise made an altar of the ground and the brine told a joke in a low voice and kept going west and east with equanimity. The rocket did what rockets do when they have been listened to enough: it stayed, then moved, then stayed, then did not fail. Orla sang, which meant sometimes she spoke under the roar and sometimes she did not and sometimes she made a face and the city read it and translated. Keziah watched bolts that were her friends and welded her hands to the air with worry. Jun wrote one line on the back of a receipt that would be studied later by women who were tired of reading only men with badges, and the line was not poetry and not law but was the thing both pretend to be: Open on the note you can live with after.

They opened on that note. The rest of it—what happens when a city decides to pronounce its own name in front of the sky, what happens when men hear it and want credit, what happens when a woman’s mouth becomes a tool and no one can take it out of her hand—was the story that would have to be told another day, in another room, with all the chairs moved against the wall to make space for dancing that did not ask permission because it had done the work and brought the towels.Chapter 9

The city wore a different sort of noise now, one with a pulse it had learned rather than a pulse it had been born with. The gutters had picked up a trick from the aunties and released their syllables cleanly at the end of phrases. Ducts were still moody, but more like teenagers who hear themselves and blush when they catch their own reflection arguing with the world. Men on stoops debated the exact minute the basin had saved the launch as if they’d been standing with their hands in the valves, and the arguments had softened in places the way rope softens when it has done enough pulling to learn it is, in fact, not alone. Orla moved through it with the attention of someone who had spent too much time under sinks and now knew rooms by their breath, and her own throat had the feeling you get after shouting at the ocean: not hurt, exactly, but lined with a memory of power that makes quiet feel like a decision rather than a lack.

Men inside the municipal building had summoned a meeting to discuss the Decibel Credit Bank, and the phrase came back to the street with the smell of printer toner and the livid sheen of an obvious mistake. You could tell who had liked the phrase by who repeated it with all its capital letters and who wrote it small so it could be erased by laughter. Jun brought home a copy with a coffee stain she hadn’t made and drew lines through boxes until the paper looked like a map of a city that refused to turn its streets into toll roads. Keziah flicked a crumb off a box of bolts in the yard and said aloud to the air, “No bank can hold that note,” and she meant both the money and the sound. The Listening kept on as if no one had tried to coin it into tokens, and in rooms that smelled like noodles and bleach the notes fell where they needed to and lifted where they were asked, the way a decent neighbor does with a couch on moving day.

Phone calls began to arrive from places where the river did not have an address but did have memory. A woman with a voice like gravel and a laugh like a slipway called from two towns upriver and said their intake screens had begun to cough and they could tell the brine was creeping up to see how the other half lived. She had no patience for the men at her council who liked minutes more than water; she had been told Jun’s name by a baker and Keziah’s by a man who sold rebar and Orla’s by a child who had seen chalk on a wall and decided it was a sort of weather report. The upstream weir, she said, had stopped behaving like a wall and started behaving like a sulk. Its operator had a badge and a shrug. The farmers had already moved their tractors to the highest ground that could still be called ground. She asked, without ceremony and without apology, if the women who had made the city hum might teach the river to remember upstream.

They took the van with the defaced mermaid because heroes and saints don’t have better transportation and because the van knew the route to water like a dog finds its way to a lake from a car window. Keziah tuned the engine by ear as they climbed out of the city’s orchestral bowl and into a ribbon of road that remembered being a path with a horse on it. Jun secured three rolled maps with a belt and told them, in the tone of a librarian telling a ghost where to sit, that the River Compact men would be there with new hats and old authority. Orla put her hand on the dash the way she put her hand on a pipe and listened to the van’s complaint and said, “We’ll stop for coffee where the sign says pie and the pie has a first name,” because travel requires treaties even with your own expectations.

Upriver, the air was less city and more tin roof. The sound underfoot was different too, a long vowel of earth that had not been compressed under brick and had none of the city’s proud consonants. The town had a bakery that smelled like the sort of bread you remember when you cannot remember anything else, and in front of it men leaned the way men leaned in any town that had not yet decided whether its river was friend or boss. The weir sat like a molar the town had never forgiven itself for needing. Its concrete was from a decade when concrete believed in itself more than the people who ordered it did. The operator in his box had the posture of a man whose job never made the news and whose marriage depended on not forgetting which box on the form meant to call before taking action.

“Garrison Weir,” Jun read off the old brass plate with the indulgence of someone correcting a book that had printed the wrong name. She had already learned the gossip of the hinges from the map: built after a flood, argued over by cousins who stopped being cousins, reauthorized like a lie that had become a habit. Keziah put her hand to one of the exposed bolts and hissed between her teeth at the way its threads complained. Orla put her ear to the sheath of pipe that ran from the gatehouse to the river like a nerve and heard a hum that was not only water. There was a tone to the metal itself that said it had been made by a factory with men who were bored in the winter and got into trouble in the spring, and it made a different sort of complaint than the city’s old iron did, less poetic and more literal minded, as if it were a man who wanted instructions and not a story.

The River Compact men had faces borrowed from other rooms where men wore hats and told time out loud. They had a young woman with them who had a binder and a haircut that left her neck exposed like a dare, and she smiled at the women the way a person smiles across a drawbridge that is going to hold neither of them for the whole conversation. “We’d like to avoid any unauthorized acoustic intervention,” one of the men read, as if he had just learned all three words and wanted to exercise them. The binder woman said, almost under her breath, “We’d like to avoid salting a county,” and Orla liked her at once for knowing how to put two things in a sentence and let them lean on each other without either falling.

Farmers arrived in their own language: boots with rivers written up the sides, faces like weather maps, hands that knew more about patience than any door could teach you. An auntie in a clean skirt stepped out from behind a pile of pallets and stood as if she had been waiting her whole life to speak to a woman who would listen. She sang four syllables in a tune that woke up meadowlarks and the weir operator put his cigarette out not because of the rule but because his grandfather had taught him to listen when that song took the air. Orla answered without taking the lead. She shook the binder woman’s hand and asked for the service manual to the gate. The operator looked offended and then relieved that someone wanted it. Keziah took it and flipped to the parts diagrams like a priest finding a psalm that hurts less to sing.

Unlike Sluice Nine, Garrison had pride. It thought its job was to say no until a clock said yes. It had a gear that wanted oil it had not smelled in a year, and a latch that would not latch for anyone who pronounced its name wrong. Orla could feel the brine behind it like a rumor in a classroom, leaning in, waiting to see if the substitute teacher would enforce the rules. The choice was the same as at the traffic circle and also not the same. Upstream, there were fields that used the river’s kindness as calendar and charm. Opening here to push the brine back toward the basin would save intakes and hurt acres where corn made decisions about a family’s winter. Closing here to save rows would let the city drink trouble a week later with sugar in it to hide the taste. There was no version where nobody got wet.

“I am not your hinge,” Orla said, not to the men and not to the aunties, but to the weir with its teeth. “I will show you the note, and the note will show you the rest.” She backed away from the place on the rail where a person stands when she wants to be seen. She put the binder on the hood of a truck and held it open with a wrench. Jun took three pins from her hair and drew a diagram in the dust that matched the one on paper but included a circle labeled “Women,” and it was not an appeal, it was a fact. Keziah looped a rope over a bollard like a sentence you could finish two ways and handed the other end to a farmer with a shoulder you could put an order on.

They did not have the aunties from the church basement but they had this county’s aunties, and their notes tasted like pie filling and anger and girls’ names whose donors had expected sons. Teenagers who had been pretending they did not like anything found they liked this, the way your face looks when your mouth holds a sound that will change a piece of metal. The men with the hats put hands to their belts and decided to be useful because a room full of women with purpose makes a hat heavy. The operator opened his window and said, after a silence that felt like a big dog sniffing your hand, “She likes B. Don’t ask me why. We’ve tried.” Jun nodded as if she had finally been given the last ingredient to a stew she already knew how to make.

It was not complicated and it was not simple. The aunties took a B and made it true. The teenagers pressed it with harmony until the weir’s pride turned it into obedience without quite feeling insulted. Orla put an E underneath when the rigging needed something to lean on and did not let herself be a leader so much as a level, correcting a tilt with her hands before anyone saw it. Keziah watched the rope with a gaze that softened into relief at the ways a knot can take opinion and hold it still without cruelty. The brine crept and then backed, not because it had been told to by law but because water listens when you make it an honest request. A field down the road took a drink it hadn’t asked for and survived it because three farmers had foreseen the resentment of the day and carved a furrow with their stubbornness.

On the other side of the county, another weir without a plaque moved because someone Orla would never meet had taught another set of aunties to hear its latch. Downstream, the basin loosened into its less dramatic work, chewing other people’s sins with the steady jaws of a kind animal. The Decibel Credit Bank needed a single song to meter and found instead a county full of women adjudicating against drought, and its software’s patience went out for cigarettes and did not return. Jun’s eyebrows rose half an inch when the error page loaded and she took a picture to show to the lanyard woman later, not to gloat but to document the moment a gate forgot its job and a commons remembered it.

After, the River Compact men wanted a photograph. They wanted to hold the rope in the photo, not because they had pulled it but because they had learned enough to know standing near work made a body less foolish. The binder woman did not smile in the picture and that made it better. The operator of the weir leaned out of his window and tapped the side of his box and said, “She likes B,” and the teenagers cheered him as if he’d delivered a baby. The aunties arranged to meet next Thursday because people like to name a thing a tradition as soon as it’s happened twice. Orla did not look for a camera. She took the wrench off the manual and closed it and looked at the farmer whose crops had gotten a little too mouthy and said, “Tell me what the drain does behind your barn,” because ask a better question and you’ll get a better plan.

On the way back, the van felt lighter. Not in the way of magic, but in the way of a basket that holds three apples instead of two because someone finally stopped pretending the third apple was too heavy. They did not stop for pie because they had eaten other kinds of sweetness and that was enough, and also because the bakery was closed with a sign that said GONE TO THE WEIR in handwriting that assured the reader the pie would be better tomorrow because the cook had a story to tell it. Jun looked at Orla over the map tube and said, “They will come to take what we made and put it in a binder,” and Orla said, “Then we will teach the binders to sing,” and Keziah laughed so hard she had to pull the van over and put her head on the wheel, which startled a flock of birds in a field and made them turn into punctuation in the sky.

The city was not offended to see them again. Cities don’t get offended so much as they change the subject when you think you’re the one making it. The basin had the contentment of a neighbor whose living room had hosted a meeting where the right people finally asked the right questions. The horns at the fence had fallen into a habit of not needing to prove themselves on days without a plan. The lanyard sent a message that contained the phrase “pilot project” three times and “community protocol” once, which is how you know someone learned something they will make into an acronym later. Jun went to a meeting knowing she would need to be gentle until the last five minutes and then unkind in a way that saves more time than it costs. Keziah went to tighten a bolt that had been tight yesterday and learned that relief loosens metal just as fear does, which is why nothing stays done without being loved again.

At home, the pipes had a dampness in their tone that meant the weather had a new hobby. A child on the third floor had discovered she could make the stairwell sing if she ran her hand on the rail in time to the rhythm of her feet, and that song ran down into Orla’s ear with the confidence of a city that has started writing its own instructions on the walls it owns. In the van’s side panel, the mermaid’s devil tail caught the late sun and turned it into a wink. Someone had written under the chalk We Are Not Pickles a smaller chalk line that said We Are Bolts, with a heart on one side and a wrench on the other, and a girl stood nearby eating an ice pop as if she had always expected to see such a sentence and was happy to know she’d been right.

The rockets held their station on the horizon like stubborn punctuation. When they finally left properly, it was early morning and nobody had been promised joy so it came clean. Men cried in private and later claimed the wind had got them. Women wiped hands on aprons and called neighbors to the stoop and let it be what it was without asking it to be more. The yard was still and then not. The long mouth of the machine opened and spoke fire, and the basin did its job without applause. Orla did not sing at it as if it were a dog; she sang at her own body so it would hold still where it needed to and flex where it must. Keziah said nothing to the bolts and thought everything a person can think at metal without disturbing its work. Jun watched the faces of the men who had become better men and the faces of the men who had found this made no difference to them and made a note that would hurt later and be needed sooner.

Launch did not end anything. It made a new kind of noise in town for a while and then faded into the kind of pride that turns into chores. After, more paper came. After, the Registry tried to sell commemorative wrenches and discovered the commons license had teeth in it and those teeth were currently busy eating graft. After, a boy moved his grandmother’s piano three inches away from the wall and found the note the apartment needed to stop damp crawling up the plaster. After, a woman at the Pickling Works started to whistle while she worked for the first time in a year and the foreman did not tell her to stop because every time he opened his mouth to be wrong he remembered a sink and shut it.

There were things the story did not do for them. Rowan did not come back and say you did good; he floated where the pipes forget and the river remembers and visited Orla only in work and in the shiver before a gate opens. The Decibel Bank did not dissolve; it became a committee with a different name and better biscuits. The Compact men did not stay humble; they found new hats. But the bridge between upstream and down had become a regular path, not a pilgrimage, and women could now walk across it without asking for a pass.

That evening, when the long day had taken off its shoes, Orla stood with Keziah at the edge of the salt flats where the cranes turned black against a lemon sky. The city’s breath had slowed. The ocean lay where it always lay, which is to say as close as it could get without starting a fight. They did not touch. They had learned that not touching was a kind of touch when the world was loud and you wanted to keep one thing that was yours silent and true. Keziah scuffed a heel in the crust and said, “They asked me again to go,” meaning the dry city with its salaries and its labs with carpet that never knew salt. Orla watched a gull invent a new insulting angle and said, “They always will. You are the thing they cannot make a machine for.” The space between them carried more words than their mouths would risk.

“I won’t,” Keziah said, and let the words be simple, which made them costly and worth paying for. “Not while this place remembers my name. Later, maybe, when it is rude to stay.” She looked at the horizon as if hoping to catch a misstep and punish it kindly. “You?”

“I’m a bolt,” Orla said, and could feel the river’s laugh in her teeth and Rowan’s old hand in the way her shoulder let itself settle. “I don’t leave. I hold. Or I teach other bolts, and then I hold less, and that will be the best day I have.”

Jun arrived in the half-light with a stack of forms held together by an elastic that would break when it would cause the most hilarity and the least harm. She had a ribbon threaded through the top sheet like a joke and it read LICENSE: Commons, Tone As Infrastructure. The city had signed itself, awkward and grand, as if writing its own name for the first time. “They’re going to pretend they invented it,” she said, pleased and tired and mean in the way that saves people, “so we let them, and we keep the real thing here where the pipes can read it when they forget.” She put the forms on the hood of the van and the mermaid accepted them as if she knew legal paper when she saw it and liked it better with grease spots.

They ate stale cookies left over from a safety training and called it dessert because sometimes a treat is nothing more than a mundane thing eaten with people who know what you mean when you call yourself a bolt. Behind them the city cleared its throat and went on. In a tenement two neighborhoods over, a couple argued about a frying pan and then sang under their breath at the same moment and decided they were ridiculous and not dangerous and laughed themselves into bed. In the Library, a flood plan from 1938 spoke in pencil to a flood plan from last week and agreed to be wrong together in a way that might make them right enough. At the basin, the water slapped its own edges and pretended it was not proud of what it had held.

Orla went home and lay on her floor and let the tile do that thing tile does when the day has cooked you. She sang one line softly that had been waiting under her tongue since Garrison had shown its teeth. It was about how the door stops being painted shut if you bother to unstick the hinge and then don’t make a ceremony of walking through it. It was about how women are never the hinge only to other people and always the bolt to themselves if they’re wise, and how wisdom is a habit of hand. She did not write it down. She put it on the top shelf of her memory where the dust doesn’t settle because the house keeps moving and the air keeps its promise to carry.

In the morning the gutters asked for scales and got them. In the afternoon a boy showed Orla a frog he had learned to carry without squeezing and a woman showed Orla the way her sink no longer sulked when the weather changed. At dusk, the first new word for what they had done arrived in town and stuck on three mouths. It was not a better word than Listening, but it did a job: Tuning. It was the sort of word men could say without feeling like they were borrowing a dress and the sort of word women could say without wanting to hide. It would do until someone coined a better song, and in the meantime the pipes, with moods and elbows and courtesy when asked, kept their end of the bargain and made the city sound small enough to hear when it needed to and big enough to carry them when it had to.Chapter 10

Summer moved in without making an appointment, and the city agreed to be hot the way it agrees to be anything that shows up with its own chair. The gutters, cocky after their education, tried out ornaments at the end of phrases that made the old women laugh and the young men roll their eyes like dice. Ductwork exhaled with the weary grandeur of sopranos in cheap operas. Children drew notes on the sidewalk in chalk, letters inside circles with arrows pointing to downspouts like treasure maps made for people who already knew where the treasure lived. The Registry attempted a rebrand on a Tuesday afternoon and papered a few bus shelters with an advertisement that read Tuning: Powered by Community, Sponsored by Us. The poster had a microphone wearing a halo and a wrench wearing sunglasses. Somebody’s aunt peeled one down and used it to line a cabinet drawer as if citizenship could be made useful by getting close to the flour.

The three of them—the woman with the maps, the woman with the cranes, the woman with the mouth—stood in the Library’s back room and stared at a stack of requests until the paper looked like a topographical feature you might have to give a name to. The stacks were tied with string and punctuated by fruit stickers, the unofficial stamp of neighborhood legit. Help us with the vents in the rec center, wrote a man who had accidentally raised three daughters into women and was still surprised by the competence that haunted his kitchen table. The clinic sent a note on a sheet that had once been a list of syringes: the exam room sings like a swamp; teach us to make it less cruel. The aunties proposed Thursday nights on purpose. The teenagers asked if they could come and if they had to be quiet and the answer to both was no if you were clever and yes if you were not.

Jun, promoted into a position that came with an impressive lanyard and the ability to stall whole departments with a phone call, set up a calendar whose days looked like teeth. She drew a grid called Tuning Bench: Parishes and Pumps, because the city still thought of itself in parishes even when it pretended to be districts and zones. Keziah scavenged a rolling cart and turned it into a kit—coils of cable like patient snakes, a battered amp, a fist of microphones, a multimeter she had named Patience in a black marker hand that refused to be decorative. Orla sorted the calls into songs—rooms that needed the A-sharp because stubbornness was baked into their drywall, alleys that wanted E because old bricks carried grief like a flavor, stairwells that needed the note a person makes when she sees herself in a mirror and decides she will keep the day anyway.

The Lanyard called with a request that sounded like a trap and turned out to be an invitation to guard the trap’s hinges. “Civic Phonetics Council,” she said, apologetic for the title and not for the room. “If you don’t sit at it, someone will, and they’ll end up naming a form after you that does a thing you hate. Come make shapes on paper that your aunties can walk through.” Jun agreed before Orla could groan, on the theory that no room should be left without the possibility of mercy, and also because she wanted to see if a committee could be tuned. Keziah went too and wore a shirt with an oil stain she refused to apologize for, and three men in suits who had come prepared to be charmed into obedience found themselves behaving genuinely because the room’s air had been altered by competence. They won nothing and a half measure on the first day: not permits, but windows; not licenses, but a schedule pinned to bulletin boards and the back of the pastor’s door that read Tuning Hours, Civic Courtesy Requested. It was not justice, but it was room.

Men who saw a commons as a store window began to arrange products behind glass. A company with three syllables and a logo that resembled a smile selling you more of your own mouth launched GateTone: Personal Acoustic Governance. Their billboard in the warehouse district showed an apartment building at night, ten lit windows and one dark, with the promise Mute Your Nuisances. Landlords bought small chrome boxes and screwed them into walls. The boxes threw a bright, ugly slice of ultrasonic into rooms where babies were finally sleeping and women were teaching their throats to be tools, and the sound made plaster remember earthquakes and cats develop opinions that bordered on sermon. In a week, the floor of the Library under the blueprints was covered with boxes; aunties had begged maintenance men and threatened nephews until they came down off the walls into hands that knew which screws would keep a device from ever being mounted again.

They organized a kind of rude politeness called a Quiet Strike. It began in a building owned by a man whose name was a rumor and whose desk had no dust because he had no books. Keziah mapped the electric, the path the chrome boxes took to sip power as if power were free if it was thin enough. Jun printed a flier that said in letters that refused to be pretty: We Are Not Furniture. Orla showed up, stood in the hallway where the paint remembered what it used to be, and sang not a note but a ceiling. The aunties at either end of the corridor held the B the way they hold a baby they are not obligated to love and do anyway. The boxes sighed and went dumb, their internal clocks suddenly remembering they were mortal. Downstairs, a handyman with a gambler’s luck cut power at the panel and shrugged at a superintendent who had never learned from a woman. The Lanyard, who had learned which committees to leave early and which to suffocate gently from behind, arrived with a form in triplicate and a voice like a hairpin. “These devices,” she said aloud for the hallway to hear, “have not been permitted for any purpose beyond making men comfortable,” and the form’s word for that was a code that made the building flinch. The devices left the neighborhood in a box, and the box left the city on a truck, and the truck driver told his cousin that women had tuned a hall until a company lost its appetite.

A school on the east side had an auditorium shaped like a secret. It had never liked being asked to sit still. The teenagers discovered that a certain sweet interval made the back wall shiver, a purr that climbed into polite terror if they got stubborn. Orla caught it before it caught them by committing the most radical act a teacher can commit in a room full of children who are partly made of physics: she told them the truth. You can crack a room like an egg, she said, and the whoops began and she raised a palm and waited for quiet to get bored and wander away. We are not cracking it. We are cooking. She showed them the difference between ringing a thing to hear its name and pounding a thing until it lies. She had them sing the A and then a hair higher and then say with their throats We are done now and mean it. The auditorium nodded like a friend who respects a limit. That evening, a boy attempted to impress a cousin by humming at the elevator in his building the way rumor had taught him to, and the elevator answered with a hiss. An auntie told him to try that noise on a pot lid instead. He did, and learned more empathy for metal in an hour than three years of discipline had taught him.

The dry city’s offer to Keziah evolved the way fruit does in a bowl: riper in appearance, softer underneath, sweet until rot set in. It came with numbers that would soften anyone’s stride and a laboratory with floor drains polished until they looked like vows. It came with prestige and three key cards and the promise of clean. It came with conditions, one of which was polite and obscene: leave the rust; we like our metal new. Keziah put the letter in her back pocket and forgot it there. She called her mother and spoke about weather and filters and the price of eggs and not at all about love until her mother asked, like a woman opening a cabinet on a mouse, “Is there a woman?” Keziah laughed until her throat hurt. After she hung up, she went to the yard and stood on the catwalk with Orla, not touching, and said, without needing the word, “Stay.” Orla did not make it a vow. She put her wrist against Keziah’s and let their pulses count each other until a pump kicked on and handed them an excuse to move.

In a drawer under Rowan’s old radio, Orla found a cassette that had no label and a crack in the plastic like a healed wound. When she fed it to a player she had kept for the sound of history, the tape rolled out a murmur that was not a song yet, something he had hummed under a sink and then spoken over—You have to listen to the space, not the note—then hummed again, lower, in the range that makes a room mind its manners. There, under the sound of his work, under the thump of a wrench against a pan he had mistaken for a tool, lived a rhythm she did not recognize. It was not Nine’s latch nor Seven’s sulk. It was an older gate, one not on any map she’d held, a Sluice with a number that had retired out of shame. She took the player to the Library and fed it to a machine in the genealogy room because the machine had the glove hands of a person who had learned to hold fragile things. Jun watched the waveform climb the screen and laid one transparency over another. Fourteen, she said, as if admitting it. The hospital. Somebody had walled Fourteen up just after the expansion under the emergency department. Someone had made a decision in a litigable mood and told the concrete to forget how to be a door.

The heat wave announced itself not with weather alerts but with behavior. Men on stoops argued less loudly because arguing throws heat from the body. The bus driver turned the air to four and apologized to nobody. A man who sold ice negotiated the price of mercy with women who had spent the morning calling old people to see which ones would answer. Air conditioners coughed into the ductwork like small monsters that flung heat out their backs with indignation and were not efficient at any task other than noise. The grid—a word that felt clean and geometric in the mouths of men who never touched a wire—began to pant. The power company issued a soft statement and a stern one, in that order, and none of it sang. Someone posted on the Listening board that the hum inside their wall sounded like a child pulling a wagon up a hill with a handle too short, and the reply gathered faster than news.

Tuning made a new kind of work in the heat: not redirecting water but smoothing appetite. Keziah met the plant manager at the substation with the expression she used on bolts she needed to out-stare. She listened to the big transformer the way a mother listens to a fever. Jun negotiated with a dispatcher at a console that would have preferred to be left alone. Orla climbed into rooms that smelled like old carpet and impatience and taught women to sing to the window units at the start of the hour and then shut them for a breath when the grid was black in the eyes. The sound did not move electricity along the wire like soup in a hose; it did something smaller and stranger. It changed the way compressors hated their own load, so that they took a breath in unison instead of five of them gasping at once. It taught certain walls to accept heat the way wood accepts an apology if it’s made before the cut. The one thing she did at scale in those days, which made her laugh three days later when she had recovered enough to admit it, was lead a city in group exhale at two in the afternoon. The Registry tried to brand it Breather Day and everybody ignored it and did it anyway.

The Civic Phonetics Council, which had been created in haste to control a rumor and had then discovered it contained women who could count, convened a hearing about the Decibel Credit Bank in a chamber where the carpet remembered feet that had run out to tell the truth and chairs that had sat on hands. Men came with charts. One wore a tie that looked like confidence printed on fabric. He explained that Tuning should be monetized in credits and liabilities to bring it within the discipline of finance and allow civic valorization of decibel reduction events. Jun set her pen down with a sound that was not a sound. Keziah’s eyelids did a thing with their edges that could cut if you leaned wrong. Orla let him finish because she was saving an interruption for a better use. When it was her turn, she put her hand flat on the table and spoke as if the microphone were a pipe.

“You cannot bank a chord,” she said evenly. “You can learn it and teach it and remember it and let it change you and you can ask it for help and sometimes it will. You cannot own it any more than you can own the rain you choose not to throw away.” She explained—in nouns the men had used and verbs they had forgotten—what a kitchen sounds like when you bring a lifelong clatter into measure. She named three kinds of tired that Tuning could not cure. She sang, once, low, not for effect but to show the carpet. The carpet answered by unbending its knees in a subtle way that anyone who had ever knelt could feel. The chair of the council, a woman who had learned to keep patience in a pocket like a worry stone, ruled that credits would not be banked and fines would not be levied on music done for the purpose of keeping buildings from screaming. The Decibel Bank, deprived of its glamour, became a grant with a bad name and a shorter leash.

GateTone did not go quietly. In the low pool where “innovation” sits when it has been told no but thinks it is smarter than the river, their engineers wrote code that listened for the aunties’ vowels and threw static at them. It caused no harm but irritation in living rooms of women who had lost their patience three minutes after they were born. The aunties stopped singing for three days out of spite, and in that silence men heard their refrigerators complaining and their own heartbeats making dull cases for rest and the static sounded like failure. Lanyard sent an email in a tone that mixed rosary and sword; the subject line read License Enforcement, the body read stop it, and attached was the Commons paper stamped so indelibly the PDF might have started to smell like ink. GateTone’s stock newsletter featured a photo of a child wearing orange ear defenders next to a bowl of lemons, as if selling problems to the rich would make the poor less loud. Their market slid sideways on a Tuesday while the city tuned a clinic’s radiator until an old man could fall asleep in a chair without thinking of war.

They did not march on Sluice Fourteen. They went like a family going to a doctor they cannot avoid. The hospital did not want them and had wanted them for years. Down under the supply docks, beyond a door whose alarm had been muted the year a man with a clipboard retired and took with him the habit of noticing, the wall had been sealed with a confidence that made Keziah’s mouth taste like tin. Jun had found the paper trail—signatures like dried tongue—and an addendum taped to an old file the way you tape a bandage on a leak when you are done caring how a room smells. Orla pressed her palm to the concrete and told it a story about memory that did not accuse it of anything. A nurse with a face like competence and a posture like a doorframe found them and made the face of a person deciding whether to call a supervisor or put her hand on the wall next to Orla’s and say the quiet words she had been saying to the building in the wrong places for a decade. When she put her palm to the seam her hand warmed. The wall, out of embarrassment more than repentance, agreed to forget the lie it had learned.

It was the most careful they had ever been with a note. The NICU lived above them and the world above that room had been engineered to stay still in storms. Orla built the chord as if she were setting chairs for breakfast, because breakfast is when a house hears what sort of day it is going to be. The nurse hummed a tone she had learned to use when a mother did not want to be touched. Keziah found the pins and asked them out of the holes as if they let themselves be removed all the time. Jun explained to a man with a badge why the Commons license, which had never been designed for rooms like this, spoke here with particular authority. The seal listened. Concrete holds grudges; this time it laid one down. Fourteen opened less like a door and more like a throat that has forgotten how to swallow and has just remembered a recipe.

The hospital learned to tune its own air. It took ten days, three meetings, and one woman whose title was Floor Manager and whose other title was Grandma to convince the administration that letting aunties hum in corridors at shift change was not a security breach but a kind of insurance you can’t buy, only earn. Rooms that had been built for flow became rooms that asked permission to be harsh. The elevators gave back a little of the sting they held for women who had been lifted through them half-awake. A janitor who had learned to move like a rumor in that place asked to borrow the tuning cart for ten minutes and returned it with a piece of tape placed precisely under a rattle on the amp’s handle, the kind of gift no committee can authorize and none should be allowed to forbid.

Upstream, the binder woman and her aunties had turned the weir into a weekly appointment. They called it Weir Wednesday because it made a kind of pleasure out of logistics and because men do not suspect danger when a day is named something that might be a discount at a diner. The River Compact glowered in the way of organizations that would like to be worshiped and have been invited to be useful. Jun sent them a copy of the license in the mail with a note that read this applies upstream and down and an old-fashioned stamp that made the paper smell like a story. The operator put a sign in his own window that read She Likes B, a declaration of love if you knew how to read it.

The boy with the hairnet became a boy with keys. He arrived at the yard with a problem nobody had asked him to solve and a box of cold pickles, the old recipe, not the hurtful acid that had got them into this mess. He had been listening to a rattle in the catwalk. He had learned where bolts go when they don’t feel at home. Keziah took him up one rung too far and asked him to look through the hole in the grate. He looked, and then looked at her, and in that exchange inherited a new job even if his paycheck never learned its right name for it. Orla taught him to hold the E the way you hold a breath when something sharp is passing. Jun trained his eye to see when men try to slip a budget under a door while calling it a rug.

The school gym became a training hall between storms. They chalked circles on the floor and put labels on them that were names and keys and cities disguised as chores. Aunties led the young in singing while a ceiling fan decided to wobble less. A pair of boys practiced being bolts by standing with their feet planted and their mouths closed and their eyes open while someone sang around them. The shy girl with the braid too tight came back with her hair looser and taught a boy with the sort of pride that makes a person pretend not to know how to hold a broom to hold the A-sharp without being a bully. A man who had been wrong in three different rooms and been forgiven in two of them sat on the edge of the bleachers and learned to keep his hands open while a note passed by, and when it ended, he did not clap, he only breathed in the right place and didn’t eat anyone’s air.

The rumor with better shoes—the one with a polished slide deck—climbed the stairs of the municipal building again. Tone Insurance. Discounts for citizens who take mandatory Tuning instruction. Penalties for citizens who sing without permit. Credits for buildings that remain acoustically neutral. The lanyard, who now kept a paper copy of the Commons license under her keyboard like a saint’s shinbone, rolled her chair back and invited Jun to sit in it. “Say no in a way that teaches them to say yes later,” she said, and Jun did, writing a policy with teeth that faced outward only in case of biting and a velvet interior that read: if you tune to make people safe, you are safe. Hidden in the footnotes was an impossible sentence that had wandered out of a different discipline: Silence is neither innocent nor neutral; do not make a god of it. The chair whose moral structure had been implied by the extra inch in its back accepted the sentence into the minutes and pretended it had always known.

They named their cart without naming it by ensuring it was always called ours. It went where it was told not to—interior courtyards the Registry would have preferred to permit, back rooms behind stores where women swapped recipes for stubbornness and cinnamon. It went to the fish market, where a compressor had been taught to whine by men who didn’t mind because they were wrong in less important ways and you had to pick your battles; it learned to grin instead, and the fish tasted less like apology and more like sea. It went to the stadium, where the City wanted photographs of women saving men’s money, and it went under the photos and tuned the concessions cooler until hot dogs could be tolerated without reparations.

The next attempt at theft came not as a billboard but as a grant. One of the foundations beloved by men who like to put their names on buildings offered to fund a Center for Civic Acoustical Excellence, with a logo already designed, a time-lapse video already cut, and a list of preferred vendors whose preferences tracked the donor’s golf habit. They asked to house it in the Library. They said the name of the library wrong and then shrugged. Jun led them into the stacks and showed them a slim volume from the 1930s, a woman’s doctoral thesis in a discipline no department existed for anymore. The woman had written about the difference between noise and harm and arranged into a table the ways a city can be cruel without being loud. “We have had a center since then,” Jun said, with her librarian voice that sounded gentler than it was. “It is called here.” The foundation men looked around and remembered that rooms can contain history that does not love them back. They left a check anyway, for less than they had hoped to be thanked for, and the money became four listening benches and six stipends for aunties who did not call them stipends but groceries.

Fourteen held. Nine held. Seven remained sulky and was bribered with oil and apology and eventually gave up its habit of sticking on the first rain. The basin took what it was given and made no speeches. The city adjusted its ear to the new normal with a huffy grace, like a grandparent learning where the salt is kept in a remodeled kitchen. GateTone tried to pivot into wellness and then into something with the word “smart” in it, and then into silence, which finally did it some good. The horns at the fence had a reunion where they did not honk and instead took a picture of their quiet faces with their children sitting on their shoulders to show them what men can do when they decide not to be loud. The Pickling Works foreman officiated, in an unofficial way, at a wedding in an alley because the paperwork could not outrun the weather; he looked at his notes and said three names almost wrong and then said them right and cried once into his towel where no one could see.

Not all of it was victory. An old building on the south edge of town sulked itself into a collapse because the family that owned it had moved to a place with air that never learned voices and the building missed names. Nobody died because a boy with a skateboard heard a tone he knew how to be afraid of and told everybody out. A man who hated Orla’s mouth organized a listening of his own in a basement where he taught boys to hold a note until the house had to agree with them, and later those boys pushed their girlfriends into corners and swore it was music; the girlfriends told each other, and the aunties came with folding chairs and sat in the room until nobody could stand to sing wrong anymore. A committee in another city called to ask how to measure it for printing on glossy paper, and Jun laughed into the phone and told them to come stand in the traffic circle until their shoes could hear, and the person on the other end said travel wasn’t in the budget, and everybody learned something about sincerity.

At last, on a morning that had oil on it and promised heat without relief, a knock arrived that had not been in any plan. A woman wearing a suit that had suffered humidity with more dignity than the men inside it handed Orla a folded letter and stood there like a gate that would not allow you to mistake it for a wall. The letter had the city’s crest on it and the Registry’s alphabetical swagger and a paragraph towards the bottom that read in the old, lazy code’s new plain language: The backdoor is closed. The door is open. Please enter any time. The signature had the chair’s expensive name on it and, below it, in the handwriting of a clerk who had learned to put grants in the right pile, the words: we kept the hinge and threw away the lock. Orla took it and didn’t smile and, after she had shut the door, laughed on behalf of the door, which had loved being a metaphor and would now have to settle for being a piece of simple wood that kept weather out and women in until they decided otherwise.

At the Listening that night—the one nobody scheduled and everybody arrived at—Orla did not stand on the bucket arm. She stood behind the aunties and let the room pick its leader. The shy girl with the loose braid stepped into the circle before anybody else and lifted her chin like a plumb bob. The A-sharp was hers, now, and she held it with the kind of gentleness that makes a room honest. The teenagers slid a blue note in because they had not given up their insistence on the future, and the room forgave them because that insistence was bought fairly from the day. Keziah leaned against a post and did not count; she let herself believe the bolts were tight until they proved her wrong. Jun folded her arms and watched the weave of the sound make patterns on the paper in her lap she hadn’t drawn and wouldn’t need to. Orla kept her mouth shut because sometimes the most radical act in a city full of elbows is to teach a room to hold itself and then step out of its light.

Night afterward came with the small romance of body heat evaporating from concrete. The cranes drew themselves into letters nobody knew yet and would learn to read only after mispronouncing them for a decade. The basin sighed. The ducts negotiated curfew with their own opinions and agreed to be quiet enough for children without losing face. Orla lay on her floor and stared at the thin crack in the ceiling she had been promising herself to fix and kept not fixing because it was honest. She sang into her palm a line she had been carrying since the day at the weir and let it go, finally, like a bird you had fed with a medicine dropper. It was the line about paint remembering it was sky. It was also about bolts that don’t brag. It was about rooms that let you in without asking who your grandfather was and what you had eaten. When she woke, the radio was telling the difference between weather and consequences and had started, gingerly, to describe repair.

In the morning, a message arrived from the county that had learned to sing to its weir. The binder woman had drafted it with a pencil on lined paper and then typed it because she respected the fact that cities like their words printable. It invited them to a gathering called Swap Meet: Songs and Knives. Bring a note you don’t mind someone else taking home. Bring a recipe for patching a hole. Bring a tool and explain why it is not a weapon. The three of them looked at the paper and said yes so fast it made the air laugh. They packed the cart until it looked like a friend moving to a better apartment. They left the posters and the permits behind. In the back of the van, the mermaid’s devil tail caught the light and turned into something that looked very much like a blessing and nothing at all like forgiveness.

The gutters sang in a broken way whenever it rained, and it rained most days of the week. Pipes were throats here; ducts had moods. The men on the street yelled and jostled and honked, flung coffee cups into storm drains as if they were shooting free throws, slapped fenders when they had to wait longer than a breath. The city had built itself into a nervous system of elbows and horn-blasts. Everyone said it had always been this way. No one rememberd it any other way.

Orla Vale kept her wrench against her shoulder in the manner of a rifle, not because she liked the look but because men left her alone if she resembled a silhouette they respected. It was not much of a trick. Sometimes it worked. Sometimes the silhouette just attracted more noise. Her van was white with a fading logo—Vale & Daughter, even though the first Vale had been her mother and there had never been a son and there would be, likely, no daughter. A hand-painted mermaid had been on the side panel once, then someone graffitied sunglasses onto it, then someone else knifed the mermaid’s tail into a forked devil-leg. Orla never bothered to repaint it. There were always more leaks.

She liked the sound of a blown trap, the slurp and low shiver. The old apartments were made of pipes and wishful thinking. If you listened long enough, you could hear chords in the water. She had heard music there since she was a kid, crouched under the sink while her mother taught her to fit a coupling, tinny radio tuned to something pop and bright. Her grandfather, Rowan Vale, sat in the doorway with his hands knotted like hose bibbs and told stories about rivers that ran sweet as tea and didn’t smell like coins. He always told stories while somebody’s hands were in the dark.

Now the mermaids were all defaced and the rivers were recipes for rust, and men who did not even know their fathers had the voice of the city. They shouted. They cut in line. They were reckless with their cars, with their mouths, with their newborns. They joked about getting “the pickles” whenever a job smelled of brine. They didn’t hold doors. They said Smile at her when she carried a pipe cutter the weight of a toddler, or else they said Hey plumber girl, you should stick to drains, and then, after she’d fixed a thing too crooked and sour for their own hands to address, they said I could’ve done that and made it look easy. Orla carried her wrench like a rifle and smiled with her teeth and billed them double.

The day the sink exploded in the Pickling Works, she had to go in through the wrong door because the foreman sent her to the alley and told her she’d like the view. “Valerie!” he said, loud and wrong. “Around back! Bring your girly hands. The sink’s sulking.”

“My name is Orla,” she said, but you can’t correct a man like that because he isn’t listening; he’s preloading the next joke. She went to the alley anyway. It smelled like vinegar and copper and two storms ago. She should have been angry but she wasn’t. It was a feeling like a frayed wire: if she touched it, she’d give out some of her electricity and have nothing left for later. So she didn’t touch it. She went in through the wrong door and into a room where cucumbers swam in hotel pans and a boy in a hairnet juggled six rubber stoppers for the fun of it. He wasn’t supposed to be juggling. He shouldn’t have been smiling. But there it is: the rude and the reckless often use the same spoons.

The sink was sulking. It was the sort of sulking that spelled catastrophe later in the week, and Orla had not yet been paid for last month’s catastrophe. She kneeled. The underbelly of machinery had the heat and chatter of crowded public buses. A grated floor. Vinegar sloshing. “Who installed this?” she asked.

The foreman curled his lip. “A man,” he said, as if that blessed it.

“This elbow is misthreaded.” She tapped it and heard it cry, a faint ring. She smiled despite herself. The pipes did sing, sometimes. You needed the right patient ear. “Sit there,” she said to the foreman. “If it goes wrong, hold the crate up. Don’t let the faucet bend.” She handed him a crate. He blinked as if she had passed him a swaddled infant.

“I am paid to—” he began.

“You are paid, yes,” she said, and shoved herself farther into the crawl. Up close the pipe told her about stress, and the bend told her about pride, and the leak whispered in a thin note about the way the brine ran warmer this week. The Pickling Works had changed a recipe. Without telling anyone downstream. She looked toward the boy, who’d paused his juggling to watch. “What did you change?”

“Less dill,” he said helplessly. “More alum. Chef says it makes the crunch sharper. A sharper crunch sells.”

“No one ever sells the taste of patience,” Orla said to herself, and then her wrench bit the pipe.

This was all before the song.

When she was fourteen her grandfather Rowan took her to the Library of Wet Things—the part of the municipal archives where maps of sewers and flood plans were stored in rolling cabinets. He had a friend there, a quiet almost-woman named Jun with hair like a question mark. That was Jun before she cut it into a flag. “It’s not the maps,” he said, holding Orla’s hand when they still walked slow together. “It’s the notations. Men drew these lines, sure, but others wrote the notes. If you want to know a city, read the notes that got written anyway.” The librarian looked like she had laughter behind her teeth but never let it out.

Jun Reid looked up from a tray of blueprint onionskins, nodding to Rowan first. Men liked it when you greeted them first, even the soft ones. “Rowan Vale. You’ve a child.”

“I’ve an apprentice plumber,” Rowan said. “And a songwriter, though she won’t admit to it since her mother told her songs don’t pay the rent. Show her the thing?”

“The thing,” Jun said. “Ah. The Thing.” She led them to a cabinet marked Unclassified and inside it another marked Oral Traditions Reference. There was a file with a label faded to a bruise. Consumption of Ancestral Voice, she read aloud. Orla made a face and Rowan squeezed her hand.

“Silly,” he murmured. “Scary on purpose.”

Jun spread the file like a fish on the table. The papers smelled of an attic. “The city had this once,” she said. “An old immigrant thing. Some families—I suppose your mother’s people—believed the first singer ate something of the last singer, so the voice wouldn’t be random. Chefs, too, but they had spicier rules. It was never codified law here, but it got into the machinery accidentally. A registry line. A clerical side-door. Systems don’t notice they are doing it. The world—that loud rude part—keeps forgetting who built the quiet rules under the noise.” She shrugged with one shoulder. “We’ve all eaten worse, metaphorically.”

“I don’t like it,” Orla said, because she was fourteen and because she did like the feeling of a secret being threaded slowly through her like ribbon. It made her feel chosen and angry at the same time. “It’s gross.”

Jun Reid, whose shoulders knew more than one shrug, said, “Gross doesn’t mean untrue. It might just mean someone wanted you to stop asking questions.” She watched Rowan for a long second. “This file shouldn’t exist. I like knowing it does.”

Rowan told her while they walked home across a bridge bolted together like a sentence. “Some things you wear like armor,” he said. “Some—like this—you put in your pocket and don’t take out unless it’s raining and your shoes are already wet and you need to know there’s at least a bus schedule.”

“I’m not eating you,” Orla said, halfway laughing and halfway not.

“Good,” Rowan said. “I’m not a carrot. I prefer to be boiled down into a ghost like everyone else.”

Now Rowan coughed whenever he laughed. Now he coughed when he breathed. He had a cough like sand. “Men are ruder than they’ve ever been,” he said one night while Orla tried to make the beans taste like anything. “Or I’m more patient than I’ve ever been. I can’t tell.” He took a teaspoon of beans as if it would lick him back. “You still hearing the songs?”

“I hear everything,” she said. “And nothing you can sell.” She was lying. She had a verse about the drips in Building Nine that made her blush in the bath when she sang it to herself. She had a chorus about the municipal ditch that came to her in a thunderclap while she ran conduit through a landlord’s very expensive vanity. She wrote the lines on back of receipts and then used the receipts to track down men who owed her late money because life is never for one thing only.

Her phone bleated. A payment app: partial. A message: come fix the valve again, lady, you did it wrong. She looked at the amount and laughed. “If you’re going to insult me,” she texted back, “do it with more money.” She did not press send. The words were, as the saying goes, clumsy armor.

The men at the Pickling Works were yelling because a sink threw its guts back at them. She fixed it. She sent her invoice and when the foreman made the wrong face, she told him his elbows were misthreaded too. She went home with brine in her hair and Rowan asleep in his chair. Jun had left a note in the flower pot—a woman who worked at the orbital yard came by the Library to look at lift designs, lovely odd curve to her; here’s her number; she said she remembered you changing a gasket at the yard faster than any of the men. Jun never wrote straightforward notes. They were always sentences with knots, leaving you to pick loose the threads.

The orbital yard sat at the edge of the salt flats, shining with opinionated cranes. The rockets had been a rumor for as long as Orla remembered, something to point to like a lighthouse: proof that one day someone would leave. Men always said it wouldn’t work, that the yard was a scam, that fuel just hadn’t been invented yet or else it was too expensive for this city. Men said a lot of things. A woman with the odd lovely curve to her handwriting called herself Keziah Idowu and had grease under her nails that didn’t come from cars. “You come by twice a season,” Keziah said. “I remember your hands. You reach into machines like you expect them to be blessed. Most of our men reach like machines are dogs that might bite.”

“They are dogs that might bite,” Orla said. “But if you make your hands into good hands, they don’t.” She blushed. It sounded like she was describing something else.

“The pumps by the fuel tank are whining,” Keziah said, pretending not to notice the blush. Then she noticed. “You should laugh when you want to laugh,” she added softly. “They’ll pretend you’re laughing at them anyway.”

Orla fixed the pump. She put her ear to the flange and heard a B-flat gossiping with a low E. She could almost hear a verse. Something snappy, something bright. She didn’t write it then. She could hear the world behind the rocket yard—men in the parking lot bragging that they’d squeezed an extra mile out of a gallon by gutting the safety valve, a boy selling an e-cigarette under a sign that said NO FIRE. She thought: this city is going to pickle itself like it pickles cucumbers—packed into brine and burning our tongues.

She had applied to the Registry of Song twice and been rejected twice because she had no Agent-of-Record and because her trust score was contaminated by late payments and because one of the gatekeepers had marked her as uncooperative. You could not simply publish your own song anymore, not if you wanted anyone in the city to hear it with the volume turned up.
